State Key Laboratory of Coal Combustion School of Energy and Power Engineering Huazhong University of Science and Technology Wuhan Hubei 430074 China Graphical abstract This review highlights recent advances in bifunctional materials for sorption-enhanced steam reforming of biomass feedstocks, emphasizing feedstock and operating effects, developments of CaO-, alkali-ceramic-, and hydrotalcite-based materials, process integration, and future challenges. In response to the urgent global need to address climate change, reduce emissions, and ensure energy security, hydrogen plays a crucial role in the global energy transition. However, traditional hydrogen production methods, such as fossil fuel-based steam reforming and water electrolysis, face significant environmental and economic challenges. As an abundant renewable resource, biomass has attracted much attention for hydrogen production technology, particularly sorption-enhanced steam reforming (SESR). This technology combines the principles of chemical equilibrium and sorption to capture CO2 using solid sorbents, thereby enhancing the efficiency and purity of hydrogen production from biomass-derived syngas. It offers advantages such as reduced costs, lower energy consumption, decreased emissions, and customization for specific applications. Although SESR technology has demonstrated excellent hydrogen production performance, existing reviews mainly focus on model compounds and still lack critical analysis of its performance in real biomass application scenarios. This review provides a critical summary of the research progress of biomass feedstocks and model compounds SESR for hydrogen production, detailing the effects of feedstock characteristics, temperature, steam ratio, CO2 sorbent (CaO, alkali metal ceramics, and hydrotalcite), and catalysts on gas yield. In addition, it further emphasizes the research progress of advanced sorption-catalysis bifunctional composite materials and discusses the coupling application of SESR technology with other processes. The review concludes by highlighting the outstanding challenges of SESR technology and focusing on future research directions, aiming to provide theoretical support and insights for the further development of sorption-enhanced biomass hydrogen production technology. Keywords Hydrogen production Biomass Sorption-enhanced steam reforming Bifunctional materials 1 Introduction In recent years, motivated by the urgent necessity to mitigate climate change, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and ensure energy security, people's unwavering pursuit of sustainable energy solutions has been continuously intensifying [1,2]. Hydrogen, as a clean, versatile, and high-energy-density fuel, plays a vital role in the global energy transition [3]. However, traditional hydrogen production methods mainly rely on steam reforming and electrolysis of fossil fuels, which inevitably face severe environmental and economic challenges [4,5]. In the unremitting exploration of sustainable hydrogen production solutions, biomass, as a renewable resource with a wide range of sources and abundant reserves, has attracted much attention for its hydrogen production technology [6,7]. Biomass covers various organic materials such as agricultural residues, forestry waste, municipal solid waste, livestock manure and algae, and there are many ways to convert it into hydrogen, such as fermentation, gasification, pyrolysis and reforming [8,9]. Among them, the steam reforming process has become a research focus because of its ability to convert biomass-derived syngas (namely, a mixture of CO, CO2 and H2) into high-purity hydrogen. Based on steam reforming technology, sorption-enhanced steam reforming (SESR) technology cleverly combines the principles of chemical equilibrium and sorption [10]. This technology introduces solid base sorbents such as CaO to adsorb the CO2 generated during the steam reforming reaction in situ, thus breaking the chemical equilibrium limitation of conventional steam reforming reactions [11,12]. From the perspective of chemical equilibrium, removing CO2 from the reaction mixture can shift the equilibrium of the reforming reaction toward the direction of generating higher hydrogen production [13], thereby effectively increasing the yield and purity of hydrogen products. SESR technology combines sorption with reforming reactions and exhibits many significant advantages. Firstly, it can achieve on-site removal of CO2, which not only increases hydrogen production but also reduces dependence on downstream separation processes, thereby reducing total costs and energy consumption. Secondly, the use of sorbents helps capture and store CO2, which is of great significance for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Finally, SESR technology is customizable and can be applied to specific biomass-derived feedstocks, such as ethanol, glycerol and acetic acid obtained through biomass fermentation or thermochemical conversion, so as to better meet diverse partical needs [14]. Although SESR technology has shown obvious advantages in the field of biomass hydrogen production, it still faces many challenges at the material level. Many studies have shown that the development of materials with both efficient CO2 sorption and catalytic properties plays a vital role in promoting the in-depth development of SESR technology in the field of biomass hydrogen production [15,16]. Compared with sorbents and catalysts simply mixed by physical methods, composite materials with sorption and catalysis dual functions show more outstanding adaptability in the application of SESR technology [17]. This is mainly attributed to the stronger CO2 sorption capacity, better catalytic performance, and better synergy and mass transfer effect between its internal components of the bifunctional materials (in this article, “bifunctional materials” is uniformly used to refer to composite materials with both catalytic and sorption functions) themselves [18,19]. These characteristics enable the bifunctional materials to play a more ideal comprehensive performance in the entire hydrogen production process. It is worth mentioning that, unlike other literature that focuses on model compounds or makes general discussions around sorption-enhanced reforming (SER) [11,20,21], this article not only provides theoretical support for biomass feedstocks hydrogen production through model compound reactions, but also focuses on the performance of materials in biomass feedstocks application scenarios, and further focuses on sorption-catalysis bifunctional composite materials with great application prospects. This review aims to comprehensively summarize the research progress of bifunctional materials for SESR of biomass feedstocks to produce hydrogen, and at the same time provide a scientific outlook on the future development trend of this technology, in order to provide solid theoretical support and valuable research ideas for the further development of SER hydrogen production of biomass technology. 2 Sorption-enhanced hydrogen production 2.1 SESR of biomass feedstocks for hydrogen production Biomass gasification refers to the procedure in which biomass polymers undergo pyrolysis, oxidation, reduction and reforming under specific thermodynamic conditions with the assistance of gasification agents (such as air, O2, CO2, steam, etc.) [22,23], followed by thermal cracking or catalytic cracking of pyrolysis-associated tars into small hydrocarbons, resulting in the production of combustible gases containing CO, H2, CH4 and other gases. The type of gasification agents has several effects on the biomass gasification process [24,25]. Air, as a gasification agent, is low-cost and easy to obtain, but it contains a large amount of N2, which dilutes the syngas, lowering the calorific value. Additionally, the oxidation reaction is strong and can over-oxidize the biomass. However, in small-scale decentralized applications, it is still a certain value. O2 can increase the calorific value of the syngas and avoid the dilution of N2, but its preparation is energy-consuming and requires high-quality equipment, particularly for large-scale industrial scenarios that demand high-quality syngas. CO2 can adjust the composition of syngas, increasing CO content, and can be used for specific chemical synthesis. However, the reaction is complex, with high requirements for temperature and catalyst, and is still in the exploratory stage of development. Different gasification agents have their own characteristics and need to be selected based on the specific requirements of the biomass gasification application. Steam can significantly increase hydrogen production, enhance the conversion of water gas and steam reforming reactions, and effectively crack the tar, improving the quality of syngas. It is environmentally friendly, widely renewable, and can be used to produce syngas [26]. It has important applications in hydrogen production and processes that require high-quality syngas. Therefore, steam, as a gasification agent in biomass gasification, offers significant advantages for the production of hydrogen-rich syngas. When biomass is gasified by using steam as a gasification agent, the water in the feedstocks is firstly removed in the drying stage at 100–200 ℃, followed by the pyrolysis stage at 200–600 ℃, which makes the large organic compounds decompose into volatiles and coke, and when the temperature rises to the oxidation stage at 600–1000 ℃, some of the pyrolysis products and the oxygen in the steam undergo oxidation reaction to provide energy. In the reduction stage at 800–1200 ℃, the oxidation products undergo reduction reactions with coke, etc., in which water–gas shift (WGS) and steam reforming reactions increase hydrogen production, while high temperatures and steam induce tar cracking and reforming, finally resulting in hydrogen-rich syngas. The main reactions involved in this process include biomass pyrolysis (Eq. (1)), tar reforming (Eq. (2)), steam-methane-reforming (Eq. (3)), water–gas shift (Eq. (4)), Boudouard reaction (Eq. (5)) and coal gasification (Eq. (6)), the chemical equations of which are as follows (1) Biomass (s) → C x H y O z + C n H m + H 2 (g) + CO (g) + CO 2 (g) (2) C x H y O z + ( 2 x - z ) H 2 O (g) → x CO 2 (g) + ( 2 x + y 2 - z )H 2 ( g ) (3) CH 4 (g) + H 2 O (g) ⟷ CO (g) + 3H 2 (g) (4) CO (g) + H 2 O (g) ⟷ CO 2 (g) + H 2 (g) (5) C (s) + CO 2 (g) ⟷ 2CO (g) (6) C (s) + H 2 O (g) ⟷ CO (g) + H 2 (g) SESR integrates steam reforming, WGS and CO2 removal reactions to improve hydrogen production and purity by driving the reaction equilibrium towards hydrogen generation through in situ CO2 removal, as depicted in Fig. 1 . In SESR, WGS is a key chemical reaction step that plays an important role in the efficient production of hydrogen. It is an exothermic reaction, meaning that lowering the temperature favors the reaction towards the production of CO2 and hydrogen [27]. Although lowering the temperature favors the shift of the reaction equilibrium in the direction of hydrogen production, low temperatures lead to a slowdown in the reaction rate. Therefore, an in-depth study of the kinetic and thermodynamic properties of the WGS reaction under SESR conditions is needed to optimize the WGS reaction under different conditions to further improve the yield and purity of hydrogen in the SESR process [28,29]. The mechanism of WGS reaction is more complex, and there are two main widely accepted mechanisms: redox mechanism and carboxylation mechanism. In the redox mechanism, the reaction occurs mainly at the active site of the catalyst. Firstly, CO is adsorbed by the catalyst surface and oxidized to an intermediate state carbonyl species (e.g. M–C(=O)–O–M, where M denotes the metal atom of the catalyst), while the metal ions in the catalyst are reduced. The adsorbed steam then reacts with the reduced metal ions to produce hydrogen and the re-oxidized metal ions, while the carbonyl species decomposes to CO2 and desorbs from the catalyst surface. The whole process involves the oxidation of CO and the reduction–oxidation cycle of metal ions, and is therefore known as the redox mechanism. The carboxylation mechanism views the reaction as proceeding through the formation of carboxyl intermediates. CO reacts with hydroxyl (–OH) species adsorbed on the catalyst surface to form carboxyl (–COOH) intermediates, which then decompose to CO2 and H2 while regenerating the active sites on the catalyst surface. The carboxylation mechanism emphasizes the importance of the hydroxyl group in the reaction and the process of formation and decomposition of the carboxyl intermediate. According to Le Chatelier's principle (also known as the equilibrium shift principle) [30], the reaction equilibrium can be shifted to the right in the WGS reaction by using a CO2 sorbent for the in situ sorption and removal of the CO2 produced by the reaction, thus completely converting CO and maximizing the production of H2. Therefore, the use of sorption-enhanced technology for biomass steam gasification process to produce hydrogen-rich gas (SESR for hydrogen production) is a very promising approach. In SESR for hydrogen production from biomass feedstock, the gaseous products from biomass steam gasification increase the H2 yield and concentration by the combined action of the catalyst and sorbent. In this process, the catalyst reduces the activation energy of the hydrocarbon reforming and WGS reactions and accelerates the reaction process. The sorbent adsorbs CO2, which effectively reduces the concentration of CO2 in the reaction system and shifts the equilibrium of the WGS and hydrocarbon reforming reactions towards the production of more hydrogen. In SESR for hydrogen production, there are two different combinations of sorbents and catalysts, namely physical mixing and bifunctional materials. The synergy of sorption and catalysis functions within the bifunctional material facilitates a better dynamic balance between sorption and reaction [31,32]. During the reaction process, the sorbent can capture the CO2 and other products generated by the reaction in a timely manner, so that the concentration of relevant substances in the reaction system can be maintained at a level favorable to the reaction, thus promoting the reaction to continue in the direction of generating hydrogen [33]. At the same time, the sorption performance of the sorbent is also affected by the catalytic reaction, and this dynamic balance can be optimized by adjusting the composition and structure of the material to enhance the yield and purity of hydrogen. This dynamic interaction between the sorbent and catalyst is relatively weak in the physical mixing approach and is not as effective in optimizing the reaction equilibrium as in the case of bifunctional materials [34–36]. Therefore, SESR technology shows great potential in the field of biomass hydrogen production. Steam as a gasifying agent provides strong support for the production of hydrogen-rich syngas. The key role of the WGS reaction and its different reaction mechanisms provide a theoretical basis for in-depth understanding of this technology. The synergistic mechanism of sorbents and catalysts, especially the significant advantages of bifunctional materials in optimizing reaction balance, has pointed out the direction for the further development of the technology. 2.2 Impact factors 2.2.1 Feedstock characteristics In the sorption-enhanced reforming process, the screening and characteristics of biomass types directly determine the composition distribution and yield level of gas products [37], as shown in Table S1. This process is directly related to the chemical composition and physical properties of the raw materials. Currently, researchers have conducted sorption-enhanced gasification experiments on a variety of biomass materials, including sawdust [38–42], bagasse [15,43], sugarcane leaves [44], rice husk [45–47], bamboo [48], sludge [49,50], corn cobs [51], and municipal solid waste [52–56]. Variations in the volatile composition and content of the three major components of biomass (cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin) significantly affected syngas composition. At higher cellulose content, the carbonyl and carboxyl groups therein are more susceptible to thermal cracking reactions during gasification, thus favoring CO production [57,58]. This is due to the fact that these functional groups break their chemical bonds when heated, and decompose to form CO molecules, resulting in an increase in the CO content of the syngas. Lignin is more likely to decompose to form CH4 and H2 during gasification due to its molecular structure, which is rich in aromatic rings and methoxy groups. The aromatic ring structure is relatively stable, but a series of complex reactions will occur under high temperature and other conditions during gasification. Functional groups such as methoxy groups will participate in the reaction, causing lignin to decompose into products such as CH4 and H2, and thus affect the composition of the syngas [59]. In addition to volatile matter, the ash and moisture content in the raw materials also have a very important impact on the sorption-enhanced reforming reaction. Ash is an inorganic by-product of biomass gasification, which is mainly composed of inorganic matter remaining after combustion. Generally speaking, the ash content of agricultural biomass is more, and the ash content of forestry biomass is relatively less, such as the ash content of rice husk can be up to 10 %, while the ash content of pine wood is less than 1 % [60]. When the ash content is too high, it can lead to slagging in the furnace, reduce the biomass gasification reaction rate, decrease syngas production, and affect syngas quality. Chan et al. showed that high ash content reduces coke production, which in turn reduces syngas production, and increases particulate emissions that need to be removed by downstream gas cleaning processes [61]. M.P. Gonzalez-Vazquez et al. found that the alkali metals (e.g., K, Na) and alkaline earth metals (e.g., Mg) in the composition of ash can promote steam reforming reactions and water gas reactions, while elements such as silicon (Si) and phosphorus (P) have inhibitory effects [62]. The K element in corn straw ash can reduce the activation energy of CH4 cracking, and the in situ capture of CO2 by sorbent CaO can promote the reaction to generate syngas. However, elements such as Si and P in ash easily form low-melting silicates (such as CaSiO3) with CaO, blocking the pores of the sorbent, resulting in a 15 %–30 % decrease in CO2 sorption capacity. This antagonistic effect is particularly evident in high-ash agricultural waste (such as rice husks, with an ash content of 10 %). Ash content also affects the reactivity of the reforming reaction, with low ash biomass having relatively low reactivity and high ash biomass having higher reactivity due to the higher content of catalytic elements. In addition, there are synergistic or antagonistic effects between the elements in the ash, such as high silica content may make K lose catalytic activity, and the combined effect of multiple elements will also affect the physicochemical properties of the ash, which in turn affects the heat and mass transfer and the final reaction rate and product distribution of the sorption-enhanced reforming reaction. The steam supply and heat balance in the SESR reaction need to be balanced. For a given gasification system, if the feedstock moisture content is too high, an increase in the amount of heat used for moisture evaporation will result in a relative decrease in the amount of heat used for biomass pyrolysis and the gasification reaction itself [37]. In some biomass gasification experiments, when the feedstock moisture increases from a lower level, additional energy input is required to maintain the temperature of the gasification reaction, which would otherwise result in a decrease in the reaction temperature, affecting the rate and extent of the gasification reaction. When the moisture content is controlled at 10 %–15 %, the steam generated by evaporation can participate in the reforming reaction while avoiding excessive heat consumption that causes the reaction temperature to drop. If the moisture content is greater than 20 %, the additional evaporation energy consumption will cause the reaction temperature to drop below 600 °C, resulting in a 40 % decrease in the CaO sorption efficiency, and the WGS reaction will proceed in reverse at low temperatures, with the H2 yield dropping from 12 mol/kg to 8 mol/kg. On the contrary, too low a moisture content (<5 %) will lead to insufficient steam supply, requiring additional steam to maintain the reaction, but will increase the complexity of the system. It is worth noting that the thermal coupling of water evaporation (endothermic reaction) and the carbonation reaction of CaO (exothermic reaction) in SEG can optimize the temperature distribution. In addition, the increase in water content can change the atmosphere composition of the reaction system, inhibiting some reactions that are conducive to the generation of combustible gases, while promoting water-related reactions. Muhammad Awais et al. conducted co-gasification experiments on two biomass combinations: wood chips + corn cobs and bagasse + coconut shells. The results showed that a high moisture content would lead to a decrease in the combustible gases such as CH4 and CO and an increase in CO2 content in the syngas [63]. The characteristics of biomass raw materials, including the cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin content in the chemical composition, as well as the ash and moisture content, all have a crucial impact on the biomass sorption enhanced reforming reaction. The differences in different components will not only change the composition and yield of the syngas, but also affect the reaction path and energy balance through synergistic or antagonistic effects with the sorbent. Understanding the relationship between these characteristics and reaction behavior is of great significance for optimizing the sorption enhanced reforming process and improving H2 selectivity and energy conversion efficiency. In the future, it is necessary to further explore the quantitative relationship between raw material characteristics and reaction parameters, and develop intelligent control technologies based on raw material characteristics (such as ash element composition and water dynamic balance). At the same time, combined with sorbent modification and pretreatment processes, the precise matching of raw material characteristics and SESR processes can be achieved. These studies will further unleash the potential of biomass in the field of clean hydrogen production and promote the large-scale application of sorption-enhanced reforming technology in the field of renewable energy. 2.2.2 Gasification temperature Gasification temperature has a significant impact on the biomass SESR process for hydrogen production [64–66]. Li et al. investigated the effect of gasification temperature on the gasification performance of sewage sludge (SS) using crab shell-derived CaO-based biochar (CSC) as a CO2 sorbent [50]. In 600–700 ℃, hydrogen content rose and CO2 content dropped as the temperature increased due to the sorption of CaO promotes the reactions for hydrogen production. But in 800–900 ℃, the rising temperature led to the decomposition of CaCO3 in CSC, weakening the sorption effect, with changes in hydrogen and CO2 contents accordingly. Therefore, gasification temperature complexly affects hydrogen and CO2 contents, being favorable at low temperatures and less so at high ones. Zou et al. explored how temperature impacts the properties of Ni-CaO-Ca2SiO4 bifunctional materials and found that the temperature has a key influence on the gas production in the biomass steam gasification process, which showed different characteristics in different temperature intervals [42]. Within the temperature range from 550 to 650 ℃, the increase in temperature enhanced the catalytic activity of Ni and led to changes in gas production. Subsequently, as the temperature rose from 650 to 750 ℃, the total gas yield continued to increase. At 850 ℃, total gas production peaked, yet CO2 increased and H2 volume concentration decreased due to CaCO3 decomposition, affecting the WGS reaction. The right gasification temperature is needed to strike a balance between these reactions to achieve high H2 yields and good product distribution [67]. In the SESR process, the CO2 sorption reaction is interrelated with other reactions, with the CO2 sorption reaction dominating at low temperatures, which is conducive to the enhancement of H2 purity, and the CO2 sorption capacity decreases at high temperatures, which affects the equilibrium of the reactions and leads to changes in H2 yield and purity. The operating temperature of the biomass steam gasification process is typically in the range of 600–750 ℃. In this temperature range, higher H2 yields and better product distribution, as well as lower tar content, can be achieved. In this temperature range, higher H2 yields, better product distribution, and lower tar content can be achieved, while also favoring CO2 capture. At temperatures below 600 ℃, a number of problems occur. And when the temperature is higher than 750 ℃, CO2 capture becomes difficult or even impossible due to equilibrium limitations, resulting in a decrease in H2 yield and undesirable product distribution. In addition, changes in temperature can affect the economics of the overall gasification process. Higher temperatures may require more energy input to sustain the reaction, increasing energy costs. However, increasing the temperature over a range of temperatures can increase hydrogen production, which may provide economic benefits when the market value of hydrogen is high. For example, higher H2 yields are achieved at 650 ℃, but it is also important to consider that higher temperatures place higher demands on equipment materials and may increase equipment investment costs. Therefore, in practice, the most economical operating temperature needs to be selected, taking into account hydrogen production, energy costs, and equipment investment. Gasification temperature plays a pivotal role in the biomass SESR hydrogen production process. It not only directly affects the content of hydrogen and CO2, the total gas production and product distribution, but also is related to the tar production and CO2 capture efficiency, and has a complex impact on the economy of the entire gasification process. In practical applications, it is necessary to comprehensively weigh multiple factors such as hydrogen production, energy costs, equipment investment, and maintenance costs to accurately determine the most economical operating temperature. Future research can focus on developing more efficient temperature control strategies and optimizing the reaction system to broaden the temperature range for efficient hydrogen production, thereby promoting biomass SESR hydrogen production technology towards industrialization and large-scale application. 2.2.3 Steam-to-feedstock ratio In SESR, the steam-to-feedstock ratio (S/F) is undoubtedly an extremely critical operating parameter, which has a significant impact on many key aspects of the reaction, and occupies an important position in the overall reaction system [68–70]. Firstly, the SESR reactions of different feedstocks show their own characteristics in terms of H2 yield and purity. For propionic acid SESR, an increase in the steam/propionic acid molar ratio positively shifts the equilibrium of the reaction towards the products. Sufficient steam creates a more favorable environment for the steam reforming of propionic acid, which strongly drives the production of H2 and CO2, and significantly increases the H2 yield. For example, the H2 yield increased significantly at a steam/PA molar ratio of 4. At 600 ℃, 3 kmol/h CaO and this steam/PA molar ratio, the reaction reached the desired state of 100 % H2 yield with very high H2 purity, and virtually no impurities such as CO, CO, CH4, and coke, demonstrating that the high steam/propionic acid molar ratio is a good example of how the H2 yield can be improved [71]. The high steam/propionic acid molar ratio has been shown to enhance H2 yield and purity. In SESR of ethanol, the steam-to-feedstock ratio is closely related to H2 purity and yield. At low steam to carbon (S/C) ratios (e.g., 1.5), the lack of steam results in insufficient steam reforming and WGS reactions, with low H2 purity (∼89 %) and high CH4 concentration (∼10 %) in the pre-penetration zone. This is mainly due to the incomplete reaction, which triggers side reactions and produces coke deposits on the catalyst surface, which affects the catalyst activity and thus prevents the reaction from proceeding properly and H2 production [72]. However, when the S/C ratio was increased to 3, the situation improved significantly and the H2 purity increased substantially to about 95 % and remained stable, with lower CO and CO2 concentrations. The Ni10-Ca90Zr10 catalysts witnessed a remarkable increase in their H2 yield when the S/C ratio was increased from 1.5 to 3 at 600 ℃ with a WHSV of 0.34 h−1. However, the H2 yields of the pre-penetration and post-penetration phases decreased by continuing to increase the S/C ratio. This suggests that although increasing the amount of steam appropriately can facilitate the conversion of H2O into H2, excessive steam can have adverse effects, and therefore the S/F ratio needs to be carefully controlled in order to optimize H2 yield and purity. In the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst and dolomite sorbent system of the bio-oil SESR, a suitable S/C molar ratio is important for the improvement of H2 yield and purity, and an increase in the amount of steam can push the reaction towards the production of H2 to increase the ratio of H2 in the product and optimize the effect of hydrogen output [73]. Second, for coke generation, high H2O/PA molar ratios in the propionic acid (PA) SESR significantly inhibit coke generation [71]. Excess steam promotes the WGS reaction so that more CO is consumed in the WGS reaction than in the Boudouard reaction, which generates coke. At higher steam/PA molar ratios, coke production is significantly reduced, which helps to maintain the catalyst activity and prolong its service life, and ensures that the reaction continues to run stably. In SESR of ethanol, a low S/C ratio (e.g., 1.5) is prone to coke deposition due to insufficient steam, which affects the catalyst activity and CO2 capture performance, and hinders the reaction and H2 production, whereas an increase in the S/C ratio helps to inhibit the formation of coke, ensure the smooth progress of the reaction, and increase the H2 generation efficiency [72]. Furthermore, regarding the reaction pathway, in SESR of ethanol, the variation of the S/C ratio has a significant effect. At low S/C ratios, ethanol is prone to generate by-products such as CH4 and CO through side reaction paths such as decomposition or dehydration, which reduces the H2 selectivity and is not conducive to efficient hydrogen production. When the S/C ratio is increased to 3 and above, the reaction is more inclined to the main reaction path, namely, ethanol generates H2 and CO2 through the steam reforming reaction, which can effectively inhibit the occurrence of side reactions and improve the selectivity and yield of H2. Finally, in terms of energy demand, increasing the amount of steam in the SESR process inevitably increases the energy demand, as additional energy is required to heat and evaporate the steam [74,75]. While a high S/F ratio can help to increase hydrogen production and purity, it implies a careful trade-off between hydrogen production efficiency and energy consumption. For example, studies have shown that increasing the S/F ratio increases hydrogen production but also increases energy consumption. Therefore, in practical applications, the optimal S/F ratio must be determined through precise calculations and experimental studies, taking into account a number of factors such as production costs and energy efficiency [66,76], in order to achieve the goal of efficient and economical hydrogen production, and to ensure that the production process is technically and economically feasible and sustainable. The S/F parameter is crucial in SESR and is related to all key links of the reaction. It can not only help improve hydrogen quality, but is also restricted by factors such as energy consumption. From the perspective of SESR reactions of different feedstocks, a suitable S/F ratio can significantly improve the hydrogen yield and purity, while inhibiting coke formation and guiding the reaction to proceed efficiently toward the main reaction path. However, increasing steam volume helps hydrogen production, it will inevitably lead to an increase in energy demand. This requires that in practical applications, multiple factors such as production cost, energy efficiency, and equipment performance should be comprehensively considered, and rigorous calculations and extensive experiments were performed to accurately balance and determine the optimal S/F ratio. This will not only achieve the goal of efficient and economical hydrogen production, ensure that the production process is both technically and economically feasible and sustainable, but will also lay the foundation for the widespread application and in-depth development of SESR technology. 3 CaO-based catalysis/sorption bi-function materials In the field of SESR technology, CaO-based sorbents are considered to be one of the most promising sorbents, as shown in Table S2. Although CaO-based sorbents have advantages such as low cost and high theoretical CO2 sorption capacity (0.786 g CO2/g CaO), they face serious cyclic stability problems during cyclic operation [77]. High temperature is the key factor to trigger the sintering phenomenon. In the SESR reaction, Ca-based sorbents undergo repeated carbonation and regeneration. In the SESR study of propane, for example, the Tammann temperature of CaO is 1313 ℃, while the Tammann temperature of CaCO3 is only 529 ℃ [16]. At the high temperatures required for sorbent regeneration (often higher than 800 ℃), CaCO3 particles are prone to sintering, which results in the decrease of CaO porosity and the significant decrease of CO2 capture capacity. In the study of Ca-based sorbents in the glycerol steam reforming reaction, it was found that as the number of cycles increases, its sorption performance deteriorated, which is closely related to the sintering phenomenon. Structural changes in the Ca-based sorbent during the cycling process significantly affect the sorption performance. On the one hand, the grain size is altered, and in the in situ XRD experiments on the sorption-enhanced steam reforming of propane (SESRP) study, the average CaO grain size was initially in a certain range (e.g., 70–82 nm) during the carbonation step, and its size decreased to an even smaller range (e.g., 49–60 nm) during the calcination step [16]. This may be due to the fact that the CaO surface is rapidly covered by the CaCO3 layer during carbonization, which reduces the contact area between CO2 and the internal CaO, affecting the CO2 diffusion and sorption process, resulting in a reduction of the sorbent active sites and a decrease in the sorption capacity. On the other hand, sintering led to the destruction of the pore structure, and in the study of Ca-based sorbents in steam reforming of ethanol (SRE) reaction, the sorbent porosity decreased and the pore diameter became smaller after multiple cycles, and the resistance to CO2 diffusion increased, further reducing the sorption performance [78,79]. The problem of cyclic stability of Ca-based sorbents affects the reaction in various ways. In terms of hydrogen production efficiency, due to the instability of the sorbent, the CO2 capture capacity decreases, making it difficult for the reaction equilibrium to move efficiently in the direction of generating hydrogen, resulting in a decrease in H2 purity and yield. For example, in the case of the SRE reaction, where a decrease in the cyclic stability of the sorbent is observed, leading to a concomitant decrease in H2 yield and purity. In terms of production cost, the unstable sorbent needs to be replaced or regenerated more frequently, which increases the cost. Moreover, its performance degradation may cause the reaction system to require higher temperatures or pressures to maintain the reaction, which further increases the energy consumption and cost, and thus reduces the economic feasibility of SESR technology in practical industrial applications, limiting its large-scale promotion [80,81]. In addition, in the practical biomass SESR reaction, biomass ash (such as SiO2 in rice husk and K2O in corn straw) will have complex interactions with calcium-based sorbents: acidic oxides in ash (such as SiO2 and P2O5) easily form low-melting silicates with CaO, blocking the pores of the sorbent and causing the sorption capacity to decrease by 15 %–30 %; while alkaline metal oxides (such as K2O and Na2O) can catalyze steam reforming reactions, but they will cause CaO lattice distortion through solid phase diffusion, aggravating high-temperature sintering. This antagonistic effect between ash and calcium-based sorbents poses a dual challenge to the cyclic stability of the sorbent (physical pore blockage and loss of chemically active sites), which in turn limits its H2 yield improvement and process-scale application in biomass SESR. Therefore, it is urgent to develop calcium-based sorbents with good cyclic stability to resist ash erosion. 3.1 Cyclic stability for CaO-based sorbents 3.1.1 Calcium salt precursors During the SER process of biomass, different CaO precursors have a significant influence on the CO2 sorption ability. Natural minerals, such as limestone and dolomite, are of great interest as CaO precursors [82–84]. Limestone is widely available and inexpensive, and in the SESR process of biomass, it decomposes at high temperatures to produce CaO, which participates in the CO2 sorption process [85]. However, limestone faces serious challenges in recycling, as its sorption capacity decreases with the increase in the number of cycles. This is mainly attributed to the fact that CaO particles are prone to sintering during the recycling process, resulting in a decrease in porosity and a significant reduction of active sites. In contrast, dolomite also decomposes at high temperatures to produce CaO for CO2 sorption. However, what makes it unique is that during the calcination process, the decomposition of magnesium carbonate can bring about an additional increase in surface area. Moreover, the even distribution of MgO can stop the CaO particles from sintering, thus maintaining the structural stability of the sorbent to a certain extent [86,87]. Landa et al. have found that dolomite exhibited excellent performance when mixed with Ni-based catalysts in the SER of biomass crude oil [73,75,88]. Dolomite not only effectively captured CO2, but also positively promoted the decomposition and cracking reactions of oxygenated compounds, significantly extending the stability period of the catalyst, which undoubtedly indirectly enhanced the overall sorption and reaction performance, resulting in better performance of dolomite in terms of sorption capacity and cyclic stability. In addition to natural minerals, organic Ca-based materials have attracted much attention as CaO precursors, such as calcium d-gluconate (CG) and calcium acetate (CA), which exhibit different performance characteristics when prepared as CaO-based sorbents using specific synthetic methods [89]. When synthesized into CaO-alumina sorbents, CG-derived sorbents (CG-AN) exhibit higher CO2 sorption capacity than CA-derived ones (CN-AN), attributed to their larger surface area, smaller particle size, and more active sites. However, CG-AN shows significant capacity decline during long-term cycling due to particle collapse and aggregation, while CA-CaO sorbents exhibit a “self-activation” phenomenon in early cycles, with increasing CO2 capture capacity as cycles progress. The structural properties of sorbents are closely associated with their sorption capacity and cyclic stability. CG-CaO has the highest specific surface area (16.43 m2/g) and pore volume (0.136 mL/g), followed by calcium citrate (CCi-CaO), calcium carbonate (CC-CaO), and calcium acetate (CA-CaO, 1.59 m2/g surface area, 0.011 mL/g pore volume). Their first-cycle CO2 capture capacities (0.75–0.10 g/g) align with this order, confirming that organic precursor-derived CaO sorbents outperform CaCO3-based ones in CO2 capture. This was mainly attributed to the release of gases from the organic precursor during the calcination process, which resulted in the formation of a better pore structure, which in turn affected the specific surface area and the total pore volume of the sorbent, and ultimately influenced the CO2 sorption capacity [90,91]. Therefore, the choice of CaO precursor has a great influence on the sorption performance in SER of biomass, and each precursor has its own advantages and disadvantages. In practical applications, it is necessary to comprehensively consider multiple factors such as cost, capture capacity, and cyclic stability to select the most suitable precursor in order to achieve ideal sorption and overall reaction effects. 3.1.2 Microstructured morphologies In order to cope with the problems of poor stability of Ca-based sorbents and attenuation of CO2 sorption capacity, structural modification of Ca-based sorbents has become the focus of current research, and many studies have been devoted to exploring effective modification strategies [92,93]. The special structure formed by the template method has a significant effect on the sorbent performance. Researchers have synthesized CaO-based sorbents with special structures using the template method. Dang et al. used carbon microspheres as sacrificial templates to synthesize Ni-CaO-Ca12Al14O33 bifunctional catalysts with a hierarchical hollow microsphere structure via a two-step hydrothermal method [94], and its preparation route and microscopic appearance are shown in Fig. 2 (a, b). Li et al. synthesized Ni-CaO-MgO bifunctional catalysts by using NaOH-modified carbon microspheres as sacrificial templates and conducted experimental tests [95]. 1Ni-CaMg6 (using ordinary carbon microspheres as sacrificial templates) and 1Ni-CaMg6-M (using modified carbon microspheres as sacrificial templates), their cyclic sorption capacity and microscopic morphology are shown in Fig. 2(c). In terms of stability, the porous properties in the hierarchical hollow microsphere structure and the double-shell hollow microsphere structure enabled better distribution of CaO particles during the reaction process and reduced the contact opportunities between the particles, which effectively suppressed the sintering and agglomeration phenomena of CaO. In terms of CO2 sorption capacity, the porous structure greatly increased the specific surface area of the sorbent, providing more active sites for CO2 sorption. The stable structure formed by the inert material can effectively improve the cyclic stability and CO2 capture capacity of Ca-based sorbents. Chen et al. prepared CaO-Ca9Al6O18@Ca5Al6O14/Ni core–shell bifunctional materials [96]. As shown in Fig. 2(d, e), in the pre-penetration and post-penetration stages, the CH4 conversion rates and H2 concentrations of CS-1, CS-2 and CS-3 are higher than those of Ni/CaO. This is mainly due to the shell layer formed by the inert materials of Ca9Al6O18 and Ca5Al6O14, which effectively prevents the sintering and agglomeration of the CaO core under high-temperature conditions and maintains the structural integrity of the sorbent. Jing et al. prepared Ni/CaO-CaZrO3 bifunctional materials with coral-like structure, as shown in Fig. 2(f) [97]. The coral-like structure of CaZrO3 not only provides stable support for the composite catalysts, but also reduces contact between CaO particles and inhibits the sintering of CaO through the physical isolation effect. In terms of CO2 sorption capacity, the presence of inert materials optimized the overall structure of the sorbent, which led to a more reasonable diffusion path of CO2 in the sorption process and improved the sorption efficiency. Meanwhile, the appropriate addition of inert materials can enhance the stability of the sorbent without significantly reducing its activity, achieving an optimal balance of performance. Dang et al. synthesized porous Ni-Ca-Al-O bifunctional catalysts using citrate anion intercalated layered double hydroxide (LDH) as precursor [98]. In terms of stability, the intercalated citrate anions formed carbon species during calcination, which acted as sacrificial templates to produce a porous morphology that achieved physical segregation of Ni and CaO particles. This physical segregation effectively inhibited the sintering and agglomeration of Ni and CaO during the SESR of glycerol (SESRG) reaction process, thus improving the stability of the sorbent. Regarding CO2 capture capacity, the formation of a porous structure increased the specific surface area of the sorbent and provided more sorption sites for CO2. As shown in Fig. 2(g), compared with the sorbent derived from the unintercalated modified LDH precursor, the sorbent prepared by this method exhibited superior cyclic stability and CO2 sorption performance, and maintained high activity after multiple cyclic reactions. Surface modification is of great importance to the performance enhancement of sorbents. In terms of stability, the structure formed by the modified carbon microspheres after sorption of metal ions was able to form a porous structure after removal of the carbon template through high-temperature calcination [99], and this porous structure helped to inhibit the agglomeration and sintering of the particles, which improved the stability of the sorbent. Regarding CO2 capture capacity, the porous structure increased the specific surface area of the sorbent, which allowed CO2 to more fully contact the sorbent surface. Meanwhile, the rise of oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface may change the charge distribution and chemical activity of the sorbent surface, and it is beneficial to the capture of CO2. The experimental results showed that the sorbent prepared by this method exhibited good stability in the SESR of biogas (SESRB) simulation mixtures, could continuously and stably produce high-purity hydrogen, and maintained a high CO2 sorption capacity after several cycles. Different structural modification methods have their own characteristics and have their own advantages, as well as disadvantages in enhancing stability and CO2 sorption capacity [100]. The template method is relatively complex and requires precise control of the synthesis and removal of the template, but it can build highly ordered porous and hollow structures, which are effective in improving stability and sorption capacity, especially for scenarios requiring high sorption performance. Organic anion intercalation modification is more sensitive to the selection of precursor and synthesis conditions, with moderate operation difficulty, excellent performance in inhibiting sintering and improving sorption performance, and is suitable for the pursuit of high cyclic stability and better sorption performance. The surface modification method is easy to operate, has low cost, and can enhance the structure and surface properties of the sorbent at the same time, which has a better effect on the stability and sorption capacity, and has certain advantages in practical applications. Although many achievements have been made in the structural modification of CaO-based sorbents, there is still a vast research space. Future research can focus on the development of more economical, efficient and environmentally friendly structural modification methods to further reduce the production cost and improve the modification effect. In addition, by exploring the synergistic effect of various modification methods and combining the strength of different methods, it is expected to develop CaO-based sorbents with more excellent performance, which will promote the CO2 sorption technology to a new level. 3.1.3 Doping stabilizers The decline of the sorption capacity of Ca-based sorbents is primarily attributed to the sintering phenomenon of CaCO3/CaO particles or crystals during regeneration. This process leads to particle aggregation and morphological changes, which reduce the reactive surface area and sorption rate of the sorbent [101]. The introduction of an inert carrier, which can be dispersed between the CaO particles, can effectively resist sintering under high-temperature conditions thanks to its high sintering temperature, preventing the aggregation of CaO particles, thus maintaining the reactive surface area of the sorbent and enhancing the cyclic stability of the sorbent [102]. There are numerous materials that play a crucial role in improving stability, among which several common inert stabilizers have drawn particular attention. These include calcium aluminates, magnesium oxide (MgO), calcium zirconate (CaZrO3), and cerium dioxide (CeO2). In the following sections, each of the inert stabilizers will be explored in detail to gain a comprehensive understanding of its unique characteristics and functions in relevant applications. 3.1.3.1 Calcium aluminates Calcium aluminate plays a key role in inhibiting particle sintering in CaO-based sorbents. Cesário et al. found that the presence of calcium aluminate (mayenite) limited the agglomeration of CaO microparticles in Ni-CaO-mayenite bifunctional materials [103]. The structural stability was maintained throughout multiple cycles. In the prepared CA75MM sorbent, the structural integrity of the sorbent remained good after five cycles. The inhibitory effect of calcium aluminate on particle sintering was also demonstrated in the CaO-Ca12Al14O33-Ni composite sorbent prepared by Kim et al. [104] In this sorbent, the structure formed by Ca12Al14O33 provides a physical barrier for CaO, which makes it difficult for the CaO particles to grow and agglomerate during the cycling process, and thus maintains the stability of the overall structure of the sorbent and reduces the decrease of sorption performance due to sintering. In addition to inhibiting particle sintering, calcium aluminate also helps to maintain the pore structure of the Ca-based sorbent. During the absorption–desorption cycle, CaO tends to block the pores due to volume change, but the presence of calcium aluminate can inhibit this situation. Dang et al. showed that the sorbent containing calcium aluminate could still maintain relatively unobstructed pores after several cycles, which enabled the smooth diffusion of CO2 into the sorption sites and ensured the continuity of the sorption process [93,105]. It also facilitates the transport of other reactants and products and maintains the stability of the overall performance of the sorbent. The stability of the pore structure of the sorbent prepared by Vanga et al. after several cycles is also attributed to the calcium aluminate [106]. The importance of calcium aluminate for the maintenance of the pore structure was further demonstrated by the stable pore structure that enabled the sorbent to capture CO2 continuously and effectively during the SESR process and the rapid spread of the reactants and products within the reaction process, thus improving the stability of the sorbent. Calcium aluminate can enhance the sorption capacity of Ca-based sorbents. Kim et al. showed that the special crystal structure of Ca12Al14O33-Ni composite sorbent provides good channels for CO2 diffusion [104]. The CO2 molecules can reach the CaO active sites quickly along these channels, thus improving the sorption efficiency. A good diffusion channel not only facilitates the diffusion of CO2, but also promotes the transport of other reactants (e.g., steam, etc.) within the sorbent. In the SESR reaction, steam needs to contact the active sites of the sorbent surface for the reaction to take place, and the diffusion channel provided by calcium aluminate helps the steam to reach the reaction sites quickly and also facilitates the diffusion of the reaction products (e.g., hydrogen, etc.), which improves the efficiency of the whole reaction system and indirectly promotes the sorption of CO2. Some studies have speculated that there may be a synergistic interaction between calcium aluminate and CaO to form more active sites favorable for CO2 sorption. Some studies have shown that calcium aluminate has the potential to boost the cyclic stability of Ca-based bifunctional materials. Liu et al. prepared Ni-CaO-Al2O3 bifunctional materials by sol–gel method [107], and its CO2 sorption performance and SESR performance are shown in Fig. 3 (a, b). The cyclic CO2 capture experiment showed that the cyclic capture capacity of limestone decreased significantly, while the material prepared via the sol–gel method exhibited superior performance. Ni or Al doping can improve the sorption rate and capacity of modified CaO sorbent, but Ni doping reduces the cyclic stability, while Al2O3 can improve the stability. Cesário et al. found in their study that, in Ni-CaO-mayenite sorbents, a special chemical environment may be created at the interface of calcium aluminate and CaO [103], which enhances the sorption capacity for CO2. This synergistic effect enabled the sorbent surface to trap CO2 molecules more efficiently, increasing the sorption capacity. The presence of calcium aluminates may also alter the chemical properties of the sorbent surface and enhance the sorption affinity for CO2. It may make the sorbent surface more favorable for the sorption of CO2 molecules by altering the charge distribution, acid-base properties, or introduction of specific functional groups on the sorbent surface. In terms of reaction kinetics, calcium aluminate-based sorbents are superior to conventional CaO sorbents [108]. Due to its better pore structure and active site distribution, the diffusion rate of CO2 in the sorbent is higher and the sorption and desorption processes are more rapid. This enables the calcium aluminate-based sorbent to process more CO2 in the same reaction time, improving the reaction efficiency. It is due to the above excellent properties of calcium aluminate-based sorbents that calcium aluminate-based sorbents exhibit good cyclic stability and CO2 sorption capacity in practical steam reforming reactions. In the study of Barelli et al., the calcium aluminate-based sorbent M3 showed a significantly lower decay rate of sorption capacity than that of the conventional CaO sorbent in multiple reforming (600 ℃)/regeneration (750 ℃) cycles [108]. The Ni-CaO-mayenite sorbent prepared by Cesário et al. also showed good stability in cyclic tests of the SESR reaction [103]. The performance fluctuations of the sorbent were small within multiple cycles, and its structure and sorption properties were able to remain relatively stable, which further proved the advantage of calcium aluminate-based sorbents for cyclic stability in the SESR process. Phromprasit et al. found that sorbents such as Ni/Al-CaO-HW could effectively adsorb CO2 in the reaction [109]. During the pre-breakthrough period, the sorption of CO2 by the sorbent allowed the reaction to proceed towards the generation of hydrogen, which could reach high levels of H2 purity (e.g., 94 %). This indicates that the calcium aluminate-based sorbent can utilize its CO2 sorption capacity in the biogas reforming reaction to promote the generation of hydrogen, which improves the sorption efficiency of CO2 in biogas hydrogen production and plays a positive role in the efficient conduct of the whole reaction. Although calcium aluminate can inhibit the sintering of CaO and improve the multi-cycle sorption capacity of calcium-based sorbents, the amount of calcium aluminate used is not necessarily the best. This is because calcium aluminum oxides exhibit CO2 sorption capacity at high temperatures and, once formed, remain inert under typical reaction conditions [110,111]. The active CaO is consumed to form an inert mixed oxide phase, so the maximum theoretical CO2 sorption capacity is reduced accordingly. When the mass ratio of CaO to Al2O3 is 90:10, the formed Ca3Al2O6 acts as a stable skeleton, which can reduce the consumption caused by CaO sintering by 70 % compared with pure calcium oxide. In the CaO-Ca3Al2O6 sorbent, after 50 cycles of carbonization at 700 °C and calcination at 850 °C, the consumption rate of CaO stabilized at 0.37 g/g, while the loss rate of pure calcium oxide under the same conditions was 0.68 g/g. Excessive aluminate (Al2O3 > 20 %) forms a continuous skeleton structure, resulting in a CaO content of less than 50 %, and a 30 % increase in consumption efficiency (CaO loss per unit area), which affects its economic feasibility. In contrast, insufficient dosage (Al2O3 < 10 %) cannot effectively prevent CaO agglomeration, resulting in pore collapse and 88 % capacity decay after 50 cycles. The optimal dosage (10 %–15 % Al2O3) can form a nanocomposite structure, inhibit CaO sintering, and keep it sorbent active. In summary, calcium aluminate plays a significant role in CaO-based sorbents. It exhibits good cyclic stability and CO2 sorption capacity in partical steam reforming reactions, and plays a positive role in maintaining H2 purity and promoting hydrogen generation. However, its optimal addition amount (10 %–15 % Al2O3) needs to strike a balance between preventing CaO agglomeration and retaining active sites. Compared with pure CaO, its sorbent consumption can be reduced by 70 % while maintaining cyclic stability. In the future, advanced characterization methods can be used to accurately explore the microscopic morphology and dynamic changes of calcium aluminate in sorbents, providing an accurate theoretical basis for optimizing sorbent performance. At the same time, the existing sorbent preparation method has the problem of using unfriendly reagents or requiring harsh conditions. It is necessary to develop a green and mild preparation process to reduce energy consumption, reduce pollution, save costs, and improve the industrial feasibility of calcium aluminate-based sorbents. In addition, the balance between CaO activity and structural stability needs to be further optimized to ensure sorption capacity while maintaining cyclic stability. 3.1.3.2 MgO In several studies, it was found that MgO has a high Tammann temperature (∼1289 ℃) and plays a key role in inhibiting particle sintering in CaO-based sorbents [112]. Unlike oxides such as Al, Zr and Ti, the advantage of MgO as a CaO sorbent stabilizer is that it neither reacts with CO2 nor forms stable mixed carbonates or oxides with Ca under typical CaO carbonation calcination conditions. Dang et al. prepared a 10Ni-CM7 catalyst and found that the presence of MgO significantly reduced the CaO particle size by characterization means such as XRD and SEM [80]. The average particle size of CaO in 10Ni-CM7 decreased from 200.3 ± 33.7 nm to 104.4 ± 18.8 nm compared with that of 10Ni-Ca without MgO. This was attributed to the fact that MgO was uniformly dispersed in between the CaO particles, which formed a physical barrier and prevented CaO particles from contacting each other and agglomerating at high temperatures, and thus inhibited the sintering of CaO effectively. After 10 cycles of SESRG, 10Ni-CM7 still maintained a high specific surface area (18.69 m2/g) and a good porous structure, indicating that the inhibitory effect of MgO on the sintering of CaO particles helps maintain the structural stability of the sorbent. The physical barrier effect of MgO was also confirmed by Han et al. [113]. The grain sizes of CaO and Ca (OH)2 in Ni-CaO bifunctional materials with MgO addition were significantly smaller than those of Ni-Ca materials without MgO addition during calcium cycling coupled to DRM (CaL@DRM). As shown in Fig. 3(c, d), after 20 calcium cycles, the CO2 capture capacity of Ni-Ca10Mg could still maintain a high level (0.53 g CO2/g material), while the sorption capacity of Ni-Ca was significantly decreased, which suggests that the addition of MgO effectively restrains the sintering of CaO and improves the stability of the sorbent during the cyclic reaction process. In addition, the existence of MgO can optimize the structure of CaO-based sorbents and provide favorable channels for CO2 diffusion. MgO inhibits CaO sintering by physical isolation, and its solid solution formation temperature with CaO (>1200 °C) is much higher than the reaction temperature (600–800 °C), so the pore structure of CaO can be maintained. According to the research conducted by Dang et al. [80], the N2 sorption–desorption test revealed that the 10Ni-CM7 catalysts with the addition of MgO had a greater specific surface area along with larger pore volume. This porous structure promotes the diffusion of CO2 in the sorbent, which enables CO2 to reach the CaO active sites more rapidly and thus improves the sorption efficiency. In the study conducted by Han et al., Ni-Ca x Mg materials (e.g., Ni-Ca10Mg) with MgO addition had a more developed pore structure than Ni-Ca without MgO addition, which contributed to the diffusion and sorption of CO2 in the materials [113]. During the CaL@DRM cycle, Ni-Ca10Mg was able to capture and convert CO2 more efficiently, and its CO2 sorption capacity was significantly greater than that of Ni-Ca, which suggests that MgO provides better diffusion channels for CO2 by improving the structure of the sorbent, and thus enhances the CO2 capture capacity. Some studies have speculated that MgO may synergize with CaO to form more active sites favorable for CO2 sorption. Although direct evidence is relatively scarce at present, the existence of such synergism can be inferred from the improved reaction performance. In the partical steam reforming reaction, the MgO-modified sorbent has good cyclic stability and high CO2 sorption capacity. The 10Ni-CM7 catalyst prepared by Dang et al. performed well in the SESRG reaction, with a higher initial CO2 capture capacity than that of the catalysts without MgO addition [80]. After 10 cycles, the sorption capacity of 10Ni-CM7 was 0.374 g CO2/g, exceeding that of typical bifunctional catalysts reported in many literatures after cycling (usually lower than 0.20 g CO2/g). The MgO-modified Ni/CaO catalysts (e.g., 5Ni/20M–C) prepared by Sang et al. exhibited good stability and CO2 sorption performance in 10 SESR of ethanol (SESRE) cycles [79]. The ethanol conversion was consistently maintained at 100 %, the H2 purity only slightly decreased from 97.2 % to 96.0 % within 10 cycles, and the capture capacity remained relatively stable. The 5Ni-10MgO-CaO catalyst prepared by Zhou et al. using paper fiber as a template showed high stability and good CO2 sorption performance in 50 SESR of biogas-calcination cycles [114]. During the cyclic test of CO2 sorption and desorption, the initial pre-breakthrough time of 5Ni-10MgO-CaO was longer, indicating that it had a high initial capture capacity. MgO has a remarkable effect on improving the performance of CaO-based sorbents. It plays a positive role both in maintaining structural stability and in practical reaction applications. It has great application value in the development of high-performance sorbents for hydrogen production and other related fields. In the future, the synergistic mechanism between MgO and CaO can be further studied in depth to better utilize its advantages. 3.1.3.3 CaZrO3 In several papers, it has been shown that Zr can react with CaO to form stabilizing compounds (e.g., CaZrO3), which suppresses the sintering of CaO particles throughout the cycling process [16,97]. Wang et al. used an improved sol–gel combustion technique to synthesize Ni-CaO-CaZrO3 bifunctional materials, keeping the mass ratio of CaO to CaZrO3 at 90:10, and changing the Ni loading (5 wt%–25 wt%), recorded as Nix-Ca90Zr10 [72]. With increasing Ni loading, the total CO2 sorption of the bifunctional catalyst gradually decreases, but the deactivation rate is low and the stability is improved. This may be attributed to the presence of more NiO species (high melting point ∼1955 ℃) or the synergistic effect between NiO and CaZrO3 can significantly inhibit the growth and agglomeration of CaO grains, further enhancing the durability of the bifunctional material. Sultana et al. prepared CaO nanoparticles by thermal decomposition and coated them with a ZrO2 layer by sol–gel, initial wet impregnation and hydrolysis [115]. The samples with CaZrO3 layer formed after sol–gel coating showed excellent stability during 20 carbonation/calcination cycles. This fully proves that the CaZrO3 formed by the ZrO2 layer effectively inhibits the sintering of the CaO particles throughout the cycling process, which greatly improves the cyclic stability of the sorbent. The stabilizing effect of Zr is still significant in the study of the long-term stability of sorbents. Zhao et al. tested the Ni/CaZr catalysts for up to 90 SE-SMR cycles [116]. Although the pre-breakthrough time was gradually shortened with the increase of the cycle number, the H2 concentration and CH4 conversion could be maintained at a high level during the pre-breakthrough stage throughout the process. It was found by XRD, SEM and other characterization means that, although the catalyst particles sintered to a certain extent after a long period of cycling, the presence of CaZrO3 effectively slowed down this process, so that the catalyst could still maintain a certain degree of activity. Regarding the effect of Zr on the initial capture capacity of Ca-based sorbents, the results of different literature studies present certain characteristics. Sultana et al. discovered that the sorption capacity of Ni/CaZr catalyst reached 49.7 wt% (5.66 mmol CO2/g sorbent) in the first cycle, while it was 51.6 wt% (8.3 mmol CO2/g sorbent) for Ni/Ca catalyst without added CaZrO3 [115]. From the data, the Ni/Ca catalyst without Zr addition had a slightly higher initial sorption, but as mentioned earlier, it was less stable in subsequent cycles. This can be ascribed to the fact that the addition of Zr changed the surface chemistry and microstructure of the sorbent, which affected the initial sorption capacity to a certain extent but laid the foundation for the maintenance of the sorption performance in the subsequent cycles. A similar trend was found in other related studies, namely, Zr-containing sorbents may not have the highest initial sorption capacity, but their overall performance is better when the cycling performance is considered. Radfarnia et al. showed that after 20 carbonation/calcination cycles, the Ni/Ca catalyst lost nearly 65 % of its CO2 sorption capacity for CaO, whereas the Ni/CaZr catalyst containing CaZrO3 only lost about 36 % [117]. These data clearly indicate that the presence of Zr effectively inhibited the sintering and structural changes of CaO throughout the cycling process, thus maintaining the sorption capacity of the sorbent for CO2, which enabled the sorbent to maintain a high CO2 capture efficiency after several cycles and ensured the stability of its performance during long-term use. In the case of SESR, the addition of Zr is also crucial for the stability of the sorbent. Radfarnia et al. prepared Ni/CaZr catalysts containing CaZrO3 for the SESRP reaction [117]. The experimental results showed that the pre-breakthrough time of the Ni/CaZr catalyst was reduced from 53 min at the beginning to 49 min at the 10th cycle, which was a relatively small reduction, and the H2 yield maintained a relatively steady state throughout the cycle. This was due to the fact that CaZrO3 enables the catalyst to maintain better structural integrity during multiple cycles, thus ensuring the stable reaction and improving the cyclic stability of the catalyst in the SESR reaction. In summary, the Zr-modified Ca-based sorbent has excellent comprehensive cycle performance. In SESR and other related reactions, the addition of Zr also helps to maintain the structural integrity of the sorbent, ensure the stable reaction, and have a significant impact on the stability of the sorbent performance. Although the role of Zr in CaO-based sorbents has been confirmed to a certain extent, there is still room for improvement. In the future, the preparation process of Zr-containing sorbents can be optimized, and a more uniform Zr distribution and optimal addition amount can be explored to further improve the cyclic stability and initial sorption capacity of the sorbent. 3.1.3.4 CeO2 Among the many modified elements, CeO2 has attracted widespread attention. It has unique physical and chemical properties and has been found to have a positive impact on calcium-based sorbents in many aspects, whether it is improving the cyclic stability of the sorbent or enhancing its CO2 sorption capacity. Multi-cycle CO2 sorption/desorption tests were performed on CaO doped Zr4+, Ce4+ and La3+ doped CaO sorbents by Phromprasit et al. [118]. The results showed that the Zr-CaO and Ce-CaO sorbents exhibited a more stable CO2 sorption capacity over 10 cycles, with their CO2 sorption capacity changing from 0.306 g CO2/g sorbent and 0.224 g CO2/g sorbent, respectively, in the first cycle to 0.284 g CO2/g sorbent and 0.234 g CO2/g sorbent by the 10th cycle. However, the CO2 sorption capacity of the La-CaO sorbent decreased significantly from 0.293 g CO2/g sorbent in the 1st cycle to 0.246 g CO2/g sorbent in the 10th cycle, which is a 16 % decrease. This indicates that Ce-doped CaO sorbent (Ce-CaO) outperforms undoped and La-doped sorbents in terms of cyclic stability. The enhanced stability may be attributed to the oxygen storage capacity of Ce-CaO at low temperatures, a property that promotes the diffusion of CO2 between the sorbent surface and the bulk phase, thus helping to maintain the performance of the sorbent. In addition to cyclic stability, CeO2 also plays an important role in other properties of the sorbent, such as integrated CO2 capture and conversion performance and sorption performance in specific hydrogen production processes. Sun et al. presented a bifunctional material (DFM) synthesized via a one-step process, which contained Ce-modified CaO sorbent for the integrated CO2 capture and conversion [119]. The Ca1Ni0.1Ce0.033 material showed that its integrated CO2 capture and conversion properties remained completely unchanged after 20 cycles. This result highlights the significant improvement of Ce doping on the cyclic stability of the sorbent. CeO2 doping effectively prevented the growth and agglomeration of CaO crystals and NiO species, allowing the sorbent to maintain a stable structure and properties during multiple cycles. A bifunctional material (HM1) containing a Co catalyst and CeO2-modified CaO sorbent was synthesized for SESRE hydrogen production by Ghungrud et al. [112] At 773 K, the sorption capacity of HM1 reached 5.61 mol CO2/kg sorbent with a breakthrough time of 45 min, which exhibited remarkable capture performance. This high capture capacity indicates that CeO2 modification has a significant enhancement effect on the sorption capacity of CaO-based sorbents, which enables the sorbents to efficiently capture CO2 in the SESR process, thus improving the hydrogen production efficiency. Therefore, CeO2 has many positive effects on the performance of calcium-based sorbents. In the future, the interaction mechanism between CeO2 and other components in calcium-based sorbents can be further studied to achieve more precise control of sorbent performance. The doping method and content of CeO2 should be optimized, and the optimal doping ratio and distribution state explored, so that the sorbent can achieve a better balance in performance such as cyclic stability and sorption capacity. 3.1.3.5 Other inert materials In the SESR reaction, the addition of other inert materials is also crucial for the stability of the sorbent [92]. The Pb-modified Ni-CaO bifunctional catalysts for the SESR reaction were prepared by Zhou et al. [120] The experimental results showed that the pre-breakthrough time of the 5Ni-8PbO-CaO catalyst was shortened from the initial 16.6 min to 10.0 min at the 20th cycle, which was 60 % of the initial value. In addition, the H2 purity (maintained at about 94.1 vol% in the pre-breakthrough stage) and the CH4 conversion (stabilized at 95.0 %) fluctuated slightly during the entire cycle. It was found that the CaPbO3 formed in the catalyst after cycling could effectively separate the CaO particles and inhibit the sintering of Ca species, which ensured the stability of the catalysts in multiple cycles. Oliveira et al. tested SESRP over 10 reaction/regeneration cycles for Ni/CaO–CaZrO3 and Ni/CaO–Ca2SiO4 catalysts [16]. The data suggested that the Ni/CaO–CaZrO3 catalyst showed high cyclic stability. Its pre-breakthrough time decreased from 53 min to 49 min, with H2 yield over 90 vol% pre-breakthrough and around 71 % for 33 min post-breakthrough. By contrast, the Ni/CaO catalyst without inert material had a swift activity decline, with the pre-breakthrough time plummeting from 96 to 23 min. These results show that CaZrO3 and Ca2SiO4 effectively suppressed CaO particle sintering and agglomeration, boosting catalyst cyclic stability in the SESR reaction. It can be seen that in the SESR reaction, inert materials such as PbO and Ca2SiO4 have a significant effect on improving the cyclic stability of sorbents, which helps to improve the reaction performance and the cyclic utilization effect of catalysts. In the future, it is worthwhile to conduct in-depth research on more similar inert materials and optimize their addition methods, so as to further enhance the overall performance of sorbents and the reaction system. 3.1.3.6 Multiple stabilizers Meanwhile, the doping of multiple stabilizers is an effective approach to boost the performance of Ca-based sorbents [81,122,123]. Multiple stabilizers can work through various mechanisms, such as forming a highly thermally stable phase to inhibit the growth and agglomeration of CaO particles, providing oxygen vacancies to promote the diffusion and sorption reaction of CO2, and optimizing the sorbent's microstructure and surface properties to enhance the sorption site accessibility. A series of Ce-, Zr-doped and Zr-Ce co-doped CaO-based sorbents were prepared by Wang et al. [121]. The stability of Zr-doped sorbents was found to be better than that of Ce-doped sorbents under mild conditions by multi-cycle CO2 sorption/desorption experiments. The CO2 sorption capacity of SGZr10 remained 0.553 g CO2/g sorbent after 30 cycles, whereas the sorption capacity of pure CaO decreased to 0.393 g CO2/g sorbent at the 30th cycle, as shown in Fig. 3(e, f). This can be attributed to the fact that the Tammann temperature of CaZrO3 (1218 ℃) is higher than that of CeO2 (1064 ℃), which inhibits the growth and agglomeration of sorbent particles more effectively. Shokrollahi et al. investigated CeO2-promoted Ca9Al6O18-CaO/NiO bifunctional materials for the SESRG process and found that 10 wt% and 15 wt% CeO2 doping significantly improved the cyclic stability of the materials [124]. The bifunctional materials doped with 10 wt% and 15 wt% CeO2 exhibited 97 % CaO conversion and excellent cyclic stability over 15 cycles. The incorporation of CeO2 played a significant role in enhancing the CO2 sorption performance of the materials, especially under wet conditions. Guo et al. investigated (Ce-Mn)-co-doped CaO-based sorbents, and the (Ce-Mn)-doped sorbent exhibited a sorption capacity of about 0.61 g CO2/g ads after 40 cycles, showing excellent long-term durability. The (Ce-Mn)-co-doped sorbent improved the diffusion and migration of O2− by facilitating the generation of oxygen vacancies, thus increasing the CO2 sorption capacity. Oliveira et al. prepared Ni/Ca, Ni/CaMgAl-79 and Ni/CaMgAl-68 bifunctional catalysts for SESRE for hydrogen production by doping CaO with MgO and Al2O3 [125]. It was found that the CO2 sorption capacity and the cyclic stability of the catalysts could be significantly improved by adding MgO and Al2O3 to CaO. Compared with Ni/Ca catalysts, Ni/CaMgAl-79 and Ni/CaMgAl-68 showed better cyclic stability with 3.8-fold and 4.3-fold lower decay rates, respectively. The Ni/CaMgAl-79 catalyst demonstrated the longest high-purity hydrogen production time during the SESRE process, with H2 molar fractions of all samples throughout all reaction cycles remaining approximately 90 %. Simultaneous doping with multiple stabilizers is an efficient approach to enhance the stability and CO2 sorption capacity of CaO-based sorbents. In practical applications, it is necessary to select the appropriate combination of multiple stabilizers and doping amount according to the specific needs, and further optimize the preparation method and process conditions in order to give full play to the synergistic effect of multiple stabilizers. This will improve the efficacy of Ca-based sorbents in the field of CO2 capture, and provide technical support for realizing highly efficient and stable CO2 emission reduction. 3.1.3.7 Solid waste The study of using different solid wastes to stabilize or dope Ca-based sorbents has improved the cyclic stability and CO2 sorption capacity of CaO sorbents to a certain extent. Aissaoui et al. prepared Ca-based sorbents containing different ratios of Fe/Mg metallurgical waste (upgraded slag oxide, UGSO) (5 %, 10 %, 15 %, 25 %) and studied their CO2 capture performance in 18 carbonation/regeneration cycles [126]. In terms of cyclic stability, the sorbent with 10 % UGSO (CaO-UGSO10) has good stability, with only a 4 % conversion loss after 18 cycles. Further increasing the UGSO ratio can improve stability, but will reduce the CO2 sorption capacity due to the increase in inert materials. Regarding the CO2 sorption capacity, CaO-UGSO10 performed best, with a high capture capacity in the first cycle and a good level in the 20th cycle. This is due to the interaction between the components in UGSO and CaO to form mixed oxides, which reduces material sintering, reduces CaO particle agglomeration, and prevents pore structure damage, thereby improving sorption capacity and cyclic stability. Gao et al. prepared CaO-FA sorbents using fly ash (FA) from 12 different sources [127]. In the 20-cycle CO2 capture test, CaO-FA5 showed the best cyclic stability, with a CO2 capture capacity of 0.58 g/g in the first cycle and 0.45 g/g in the 20th cycle, which is significantly better than the 56.50 % loss of pure CaO. This enhanced performance is attributed to the uniform dispersion of inert materials in FA5, which effectively mitigates the sintering of CaO particles. Yan et al. prepared red mud (RM)-doped Ca-Al-Ce bifunctional materials for CO2 capture in the process of SESR [43]. The RM-doped Ca-Al-Ce material (RM5-Ca75Al10Ce15) showed good cyclic stability in 20 CO2 capture cycles. Its CO2 sorption capacity after 20 cycles is improved compared with that of undoped materials. During the biomass steam gasification process, the RM5-Ca75Al10Ce15 material had a higher H2 concentration and a lower CO2 concentration at the 20th cycle, which was due to the improved CO2 capture activity of the material by RM.
