At the same time, it is necessary to strengthen collaborative research with high-performance catalysts, explore the best combination of the two in the SESR process, so as to achieve more stable and efficient CO2 capture and conversion, and promote SESR technology towards large-scale industrial applications. 4.2 Synergistic application of diverse catalysts with alkali-metal sorbents in SESR In the SESR process, in situ capture of CO2 is of great significance for breaking the reaction balance and increasing the hydrogen concentration, but the low gasification reaction rate has become a key factor restricting the efficient production of high-concentration H2. The researchers prepared a bifunctional material by adding a catalyst to an alkali metal sorbent, which has the ability to efficiently sorb CO2 while increasing the gasification reaction rate to maximize the production of high-concentration H2. 4.2.1 Ni-based catalyst Ni-based catalysts are a typical metal catalyst with great application potential in tar conversion and biomass gasification. There are two ways to combine Ni-based catalysts with alkali metal sorbents for SER hydrogen production: physical mixing and bifunctional materials. The physical mixing method has the advantages of flexible operation and easy preparation, but has limited contact effect and mass transfer problems [213]. Compared with the physical mixing method of catalyst and sorbent, bifunctional materials significantly improve the mass transfer problem. Wang et al. tested the performance of NiO/NiAl2O4 catalyst and Li2ZrO3-based sorbent in SESRG reaction [190]. In the reaction, the catalyst displayed excellent activity and stability. In addition, a high glycerol conversion rate was achieved by it, and the hydrogen selectivity was as high as 99.59 % in the initial stage of the reaction. As the number of cycles increased, the purity of hydrogen decreased, but it was still higher than the traditional thermodynamic calculation limit (67 %), as shown in Fig. 9 (a). At the same time, the CO2 capture capacity of Li2ZrO3-based sorbent decreased during the cycle, but the synergistic effect with the catalyst could still achieve a good reaction effect. Wang et al. prepared Ni/Al2O3 catalysts containing 15 wt% Ni by three methods: sol–gel, impregnation, and co-precipitation [199]. The SG-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst prepared by the sol–gel method had the best hydrogen selectivity (81 %). The optimized SG-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was combined with the RH-Li4SiO4 sorbent in different loading methods for SESR of ethanol reaction. It was found that the four-layer interval loading (catalyst in the upper layer) showed the best performance in 10 consecutive cycles, and the hydrogen selectivity was stable above 93 %, achieving efficient production of high-purity hydrogen. Zhang et al. prepared K2CO3-doped Li4SiO4 sorbent (K-Li4SiO4) and Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst by solid-state reaction method [197]. The performance of the sorbent and the catalyst in methane steam reforming reaction was studied in a fixed bed reactor. Fig. 9(b) shows that K-Li4SiO4 sorbent exhibits good CO2 sorption performance at 550 ℃, and synergistically interacting with the catalyst significantly improves hydrogen production and CH4 conversion rate, and hydrogen production can reach more than 95 % in the early stage of the reaction. In addition, the study also found that in situ enhancement and moderate particle size (20–40 mesh) are beneficial to the reaction system, which is related to the contact effect between the sorbent and the catalyst and the gas diffusion performance. Liu et al. prepared Fe-Ni bimetallic oxide and K2CO3-promoted Li4SiO4 particles (K-Li4SiO4) [198]. The bimetallic oxide particles maintained an oxygen transfer capacity of 57.4 % at 600 ℃ and showed high stability over 200 redox cycles. In the reaction, as the mass ratio of absorbent to metal oxide (MCO3/MO) increased from 0 to 7/4, the hydrogen production increased significantly and the volume flow rates of CO and CO2 decreased remarkably. This is mainly due to the enhancement of CO2 capture capacity and the promotion of WGS reaction. Xie et al. developed a novel K x -Li4SiO4@Niγ bifunctional material [214]. As shown in Fig. 9(c), in a fixed bed reactor, the effects of K doping and Ni loading on CO2 sorption capacity were compared with other K x -Li4SiO4@Niγ materials. Among them, K0.2-Li4SiO4@Ni10 showed the highest sorption capacity (4.59 mmol/g), which was much higher than K0.2-Li4SiO4 (1.975 mmol/g) and Li4SiO4@Ni10 (1.826 mmol/g), which once again confirmed the promotion of K-Ni interaction on CO2 sorption. As shown in Fig. 9(d), within the temperature range of 500–600 ℃, the capture capacity of K0.2-Li4SiO4@Ni10 increased with the increase in temperature and reached the optimum at 550 ℃. Further heating to 600 ℃ causes the CO2 release rate to be too fast and unable to be converted in time, causing the CO2 conversion efficiency to drop rapidly to 41.3 %. This shows that 550 ℃ is the optimal temperature for achieving efficient CO2 sorption and in situ catalytic conversion at the same time. This temperature is conducive to the sorption of CO2 and can put LiKCO3 in a suitable state to promote the diffusion of H2 and CO2 molecules to the internal sorption and catalytic active sites, thereby achieving efficient conversion. González et al. synthesized Li4SiO4 through solid-state reaction, and used a wet impregnation method to deposit 10 wt% NiO on the surface of Li4SiO4 to prepare NiO-Li4SiO4 composite materials [201]. In the isothermal experiment, the CO2 capture of NiO-Li4SiO4 increased with increasing temperature, reaching the optimum at 675 ℃, and no obvious desorption process was observed, indicating that the deposition of NiO significantly improved the CO2 capture performance of Li4SiO4, mainly because of the growth in the number of surface basic sites. In the DRM reaction, Li4SiO4 has almost no catalytic activity, while NiO-Li4SiO4 shows good catalytic activity above 750 ℃, and hydrogen production is detected starting from 750 ℃ and increases with increasing temperature, reaching the maximum value (75 %) at 860 ℃, and the H2/CO ratio is greater than 1 above 828 ℃, showing good selectivity for hydrogen production. Babu et al. prepared Li2CuO2 through solid-state reaction, and synthesized a series of Ni-based hybrid materials containing different proportions of Al2O3 and Li2CuO2 (such as HM-50, etc.) [206]. The SRE reaction was carried out in a continuous fixed-bed downflow reactor, and the selected HM-50 material showed excellent performance under the optimal reaction conditions (700 ℃, feed flow rate 0.5 mL/min, S/C = 6) Performance, glycerol conversion rate reaches 100 %, H2 yield is 90 %, and H2 purity is 94 mol%. CO2-TPD analysis shows that HM-50 has high alkalinity, which is beneficial to CO2 sorption, thus promoting the improvement of H2 purity. Peltzer et al. synthesized the bifunctional catalyst NiKLiZr, which achieved a capture efficiency of 50 % at 500 ℃ and 50 % CO2 in CO2-TPD experiments [192]. It showed good stability in 10 consecutive sorption/desorption cycles (500 ℃, 15 % CO2, 20 % H2O, 60 min reaction) with an average capture capacity of 0.075 g CO2/g mat. In the SRE reaction, NiKLiZr has an initial ethanol conversion rate of about 85 % at GHSV = 13250 h−1. Babu et al. synthesized three materials: Ni/Al2O3, Ni/Li2ZrO3 and Ni/Al2O3/ Li2ZrO3 (HM-50, where Li2ZrO3 and Al2O3 mass percentages are equal) [31]; the Ni loading was all 10 wt%, where HM-50 performs best. Increasing temperature increased the EG conversion from 63 % at 450 ℃ to 100 % at 650 ℃ and above, and the hydrogen concentration increased from 58 % to 82 % at 450–650 ℃, but decreased from time to time at 700 ℃ and 750 ℃. The hydrogen concentration of HM-50 was >90 % before 11 sorption–desorption cycles. After 15 cycles, it lost most of its sorption performance and the hydrogen concentration dropped to 74 %, which was the same as the hydrogen concentration of ethylene glycol steam reforming on the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. This was mainly due to the structural change of Li2ZrO3 after cycling, resulting in the loss of reversibility. It can be found that although the bifunctional material combining Ni-based catalyst and alkali metal sorbent is beneficial to close collaboration and improved mass transfer, it has many problems. Future research can be devoted to further optimizing the composition and structure of Ni-based bifunctional materials, and deeply exploring the effects of different element doping and loading methods on material performance, so as to improve the catalyst activity and sorption performance of the sorbent, and enhance the synergistic effect of the two. It is also possible to explore the long-term stability and adaptability of Ni-based bifunctional material systems under more complex partical working conditions, such as those containing a variety of impurity gases or under different temperature and pressure conditions. In addition, research on the reaction mechanism should be strengthened, especially the microscopic mechanism in the process of CO2 sorption and in situ catalytic conversion, to provide theoretical support for the design and development of more efficient Ni-based bifunctional materials. In terms of industrial application, it is necessary to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of the system, optimize the preparation process, reduce production costs, and improve production efficiency to promote its widespread application in partical industrial production. 4.2.2 Noble metal catalysts Noble metal catalysts (such as Pt, Rh, Ru, etc.) play a vital role in a variety of chemical reactions. This type of catalyst has the advantages of high activity, high selectivity and good stability. However, they also have limitations such as high cost and resource scarcity. Currently, researchers are conducting some research on the direction of combining noble metal catalysts with alkali metal sorbents for SESR. Halabi et al. explored the reaction kinetic characteristics and sorbent capacity requirements when the Rh/Ce2Zr1− a O2 catalyst was combined with the Li2ZrO3 sorbent [215]. The sorption kinetics of Li2ZrO3 is of great significance in determining the reaction performance. When the CO2 sorption rate constant kCO2 increased from 3.3 × 10−5 m3/(mol s) to 3.3 × 10−2 m3/(mol s), the CH4 conversion rate increased from 69 % to 98 %, and the CO2 escape amount decreased to <245 ppm. This shows that, when working in conjunction with a highly active Rh catalyst, the fast sorption kinetics of the sorbent play a decisive role in breaking the reaction equilibrium limit and improving the CH4 conversion rate and H2 purity. Ail et al. focused on the performance of the combination of Li4SiO4 sorbent and 1 wt% Pt/Al2O3 catalyst [216]. The study found that temperature and S/C ratio significantly affected the reaction performance. The hydrogen yield increased the most at 600 °C, and the best effect was achieved at S/C = 1.7. There are few studies on combining noble metal catalysts with alkali metal sorbents for SER reactions, and most of them focus on the physical mixing of catalysts and sorbents. In the future, the catalyst-sorbent combination needs to be further optimized to reduce internal diffusion resistance and improve reaction efficiency by accurately controlling its distribution and interaction. In conclusion, in the SESR process, combining catalysts with alkali metal sorbents to prepare bifunctional materials is crucial to improving the gasification reaction rate and high-concentration hydrogen production. Although the bifunctional materials combining Ni-based catalysts with alkali metal sorbents can improve the synergistic effect and solve transfer problems, their stability is poor, and it is necessary to study modification methods to improve their structural stability and cycle life. The combination of noble metal catalysts and alkali metal sorbents can improve reaction performance, but current related research is mostly focused on physical mixing, and the optimization of the combination method is insufficient. Notably, there is a lack of literature exploring alkali metal sorbent bifunctional materials for biomass sorption-enhanced reforming to produce hydrogen, hindering practical discussions on their performance in real biomass applications—especially regarding how alkali metal components interact with biomass ash (e.g., SiO2, K2O) and whether they can mitigate sintering or pore blockage issues during long-term operation. In the future, on the one hand, new modification strategies should be explored to enhance the stability of Ni-based bifunctional materials, with specific attention to their resistance to biomass-derived impurities (such as chlorine or alkali metals) that might cause catalyst poisoning. On the other hand, for the combination of noble metal catalysts and alkali metal sorbents, it is necessary to precisely control the distribution and interaction of the two, reduce the internal diffusion resistance, and improve the reaction efficiency in complex biomass-derived gas streams. Additionally, exploring cost-reduction methods—such as using industrial waste-derived alkali metal sorbents or developing scalable synthesis processes—will be critical to promoting the technology toward practical application in biomass-to-hydrogen conversion. Experimental studies should also prioritize evaluating how bifunctional materials perform in real biomass SESR systems, including their tolerance to ash components and their ability to maintain activity across multiple cycles with actual biomass feedstocks. 5 Hydrotalcite-based catalytic/sorption bifunctional materials 5.1 Hydrotalcite sorbent cyclic CO2 capture capacity Hydrotalcite (HTlc) sorbents are a class of materials with important application potential in the field of CO2 sorption steam reforming [217], as shown in Table S4. Hydrotalcite is an anionic clay, and the positively charged metal hydroxide layers make up its crystal structure (formed by partial substitution of divalent cations by trivalent cations), negatively charged interlayer anions (such as carbonate ions) and water molecules. The sorption temperature range of HTlc materials is quite wide, from 20 ℃ to 400 ℃. Although its sorption capacity is at a medium level, it has excellent comprehensive performance in combination with good cyclic stability and low regeneration energy consumption. The process of CO2 sorption by hydrotalcite usually includes two stages: rapid sorption and slow sorption. In the initial stage, the sorption rate is fast, the sorption rate tends to slow down gradually until equilibrium is achieved, as the sorption progresses. Different hydrotalcite sorbents, under different experimental conditions have different sorption kinetic behaviors. For example, among the hydrotalcite sorbents promoted by alkali metals (Na, Cs and K), the Cs-promoted samples show better performance in sorption kinetics and can achieve higher sorption amounts in a relatively short time. Under appropriate conditions, some hydrotalcite sorbents can achieve high CO2 sorption. Hydrotalcite has good sorption selectivity for CO2 and can preferentially adsorb CO2 in a variety of gas mixtures. In practical biomass SESR, hydrotalcite demonstrates unique advantages over CaO-based sorbents. Ash in biomass reduces the sorption capacity of CaO, whereas hydrotalcite avoids such interactions. Instead, alkali metal oxides in the ash can synergize with the anionic structure of hydrotalcite, potentially enhancing its catalytic activity for steam reforming without causing lattice distortion or sintering. This structural compatibility mitigates the dual challenges of physical pore blockage and loss of chemical active sites, enabling hydrotalcite to maintain high H2 yields and facilitate the scaling of biomass SESR processes. Notably, the CO2 sorption selectivity of hydrotalcite (preferentially adsorbing CO2 from complex gas mixtures) is particularly valuable for capturing CO2 from biomass pyrolysis gas, ensuring efficient separation and improving hydrogen purity. However, long-term operation in biomass SESR may still face challenges from biomass impurities, which could affect the sorbent's structural stability. Therefore, developing hydrotalcite sorbents with high sorption capacity and cyclic stability is crucial for advancing SESR technology toward large-scale hydrogen production from biomass. To solve these problems, researchers have conducted extensive research. Kim et al. adopted an improved coprecipitation method to synthesize hydrotalcite-based sorbents containing sodium nitrate and a Mg/Al molar ratio of 20–30 [218]. Studies have shown that the increase in the Mg/Al molar ratio, the increase in the sodium nitrate content, and the molten salt state at nearly 308 ℃ affect the sorption performance. In the dynamic CO2 sorption test, Mg30Al1 has the largest capture capacity owing to the highest sodium nitrate content. The sample in the range of 250–400 ℃ has the largest sorption at 275 ℃. Salomé Macedo et al. prepared hydrotalcite by coprecipitation [219]. The synthesized 8.5HT7 sample (Mg/Al molar ratio of 7, synthesis pH of 8.5) has a sorption capacity of up to 1.62 mmol/g under 300 ℃ and 1 bar of CO2, which is much higher than some commercial materials and samples in other similar studies. Catarina Faria et al. prepared a sorbent with good cyclic stability by optimizing the material composition and preparation method [220]. The Ni-substituted hydrotalcite bifunctional extrudates showed excellent stability in continuous cyclic operation, and could completely convert the captured CO2 into methane without CO production at 350 ℃ and 1 bar. They also used an alkali metal (such as Na, Cs, K) impregnation method to effectively increase the basic sites of the sorbent, thereby improving the CO2 sorption capacity [221]. Among them, the CHT-10Cs sample (doped with 9.4 wt% Cs) showed excellent sorption performance, and the cyclic working capacity reached 0.32 mol/kg under 573 K and 0.15 bar CO2 conditions. They found that alkali metal doping exerts a substantial influence on the sorption kinetics, and the sorption rate can be optimized by adjusting the composition of the sorbent. Additionally, they studied the effect of other components commonly found in flue gases, such as oxygen, steam, and CO, on the cyclic working capacity of the CHT-10Cs sample. When the oxygen content increases from 5 vol% to 10 vol%, the relative increase in cycle working capacity is about 22 %, and the cyclic working capacity increases by about 44 % relative to the addition of 20 vol% steam. The presence of CO has no significant impact on cyclic working capacity. Rocha et al. synthesized hydrotalcite-based sorbents with different interlayer anions (carbonate and triacetic acid borohydride anions) and found that the type of interlayer anions significantly affects the performance of the sorbent [222]. Under sorption conditions containing steam, sorbents with triacetic acid borohydride anions as interlayer anions (HTC-Long series) exhibit different behaviors from sorbents with carbonate as interlayer anions (HTC-CO3 series). Steam is detrimental to the sorption capacity of HTC-Long series sorbents. This indicates that the adaptability of the sorbent to different operating conditions can be tuned by selecting appropriate interlayer anions, especially in the presence of steam. Hydrotalcite (HT) sorbents have shown good application potential in SESR field due to their unique structure and properties [188,223]. Researchers have conducted extensive research on the application of hydrotalcite sorbents in SER reactions. Dewoolkar et al. synthesized two hydrotalcite-based hybrid materials, Ni-HTc (HM1) and Ni-CaO/Al2O3 (HM2) [224]. In the SE-SMR reaction, HM1 achieved a CH4 conversion rate of 90 % at 673 K and a CO2 sorption capacity of 1.1 mol/kg; HM2 achieved a maximum CH4 conversion rate of 92.8 % at 823 K and a capture capacity of 12.3 mol/kg. Both materials have good cyclic stability, with the performance of HM1 decreasing after 16 cycles and HM2 decreasing after 11 cycles. This study shows that hydrotalcite-based hybrid materials have good performance in SE-SMR, but the high-temperature stability and regeneration temperature of HM2 need to be further optimized. Ghungrud et al. prepared three cobalt catalysts loaded on hydrotalcite materials promoted by calcium [225], copper and zinc (Co-Ca-HTlc, Co-Cu-HTlc and Co-Zn-HTlc, respectively denoted as HM1, HM2 and HM3). Breakthrough experiments showed that the breakthrough times of HM1, HM2 and HM3 were 15, 25 and 10 min, respectively, and the sorption capacities were 0.58, 0.66 and 0.38 mol CO2/kg sorbent, respectively. As the temperature increases, the hydrogen content and sorption capacity of HM2 increase, and the sorption capacity reaches 0.81 mol CO2/kg sorbent at 823 K. Qi et al. discovered that K-hydrotalcite has decarbonization at around 680 K [226], which is conducive to regeneration. Its CO2 sorption capacity at 673 K and 0.8 mmol CO2/kg sorbent is about 30 % higher than that of unmodified hydrotalcite. They found that different loading modes of sorbent and catalyst have a significant effect on reaction performance, and attention should be paid to the synergistic relationship between catalyst and sorbent to improve reaction performance. Arstad et al. synthesized a series of K-promoted Co x Mg3− x Al oxide sorbents based on hydrotalcite [227], and tested their CO2 sorption performance in SEWGS reaction in a fixed-bed reactor. In preliminary tests, the cycling capacity of the Co1.5Mg1.5Al(22) material was about 10 %–12 % higher than that of the reference material at 400 ℃ and 17 %–25 % higher at 375 ℃. Long-term tests showed that the Co1.5Mg1.5Al(22) material was stable, and its volumetric capacity was estimated to be 23 %–26 % higher at 400 ℃ and 30 %–39 % higher at 375 ℃ than that of the reference material. Avendaño et al. studied the performance of K-modified Mg/Al hydrotalcite for SESRE hydrogen production [228]. According to Fig. 10 (a, b), multi-cyclic stability tests show that the K-modified sorbent has high stability, and 15KHT (5 0 0) has the highest cycle CO2 sorption capacity. Its stable distribution of basic sites explains the good cyclic stability, while the loss of stability of 10KHT (5 0 0) may be related to the low proportion of strong basic sites, and 20KHT (5 0 0) may have poor stability due to K crystal phase segregation. Therefore, it can be found that hydrotalcite sorbents occupy a significant position in SESR reactions. Although its sorption capacity is at a medium level, it has good cyclic stability and requires low regeneration energy consumption. Researchers have achieved certain results by improving preparation methods, optimizing material composition, adjusting interlayer anions, etc., and hydrotalcite sorbents have shown an improvement in reaction performance in SESR reactions. However, it still faces problems such as the need to improve sorption capacity, enhance cyclic stability, optimize sorption kinetics, and reduce high cost. In the future, the preparation process of hydrotalcite sorbents needs to be further optimized to significantly improve their sorption performance and stability. In-depth exploration of the reaction mechanisms in different reaction systems and clarification of the nature of their action will enable a more efficient use of its advantages and promote its widespread application in the SESR field. 5.2 Synergistic application of diverse catalysts with hydrotalcite sorbents in SESR In the SER reaction, in addition to the hydrotalcite sorbent, the catalyst also plays a vital role [229]. It can significantly improve the reaction performance and promote the efficient production of hydrogen. Avendaño et al. found that the NiMgAl catalyst can effectively improve H2 purity when mixed with K-promoted hydrotalcite in the SESRE reaction [228]. As shown in Fig. 10(c), in SRE, K-modified hydrotalcite improves the H2 purity. In a short time (<5 min), the H2 purity is higher than 95 %, and the CO2 concentration is close to 0 %. In the three-cycle test, the H2 purity of the K-modified sorbent is high. The H2 purity of 15KHT (5 0 0) remains stable at more than 90 % in three cycles, and 10KHT (5 0 0) and 20KHT (5 0 0) decrease slightly in the third cycle, but are still significantly higher than the H2 purity of traditional SRE (>80 %). Therefore, K enhances the sorption of CO2 in SESR, and high-purity H2 can be obtained in a short time, while CO2 is effectively captured. Marin et al. synthesized Ni-containing hydrotalcite bifunctional materials through the co-precipitation method [230]. In the CO2 sorption test at different temperatures, the presence of Ni in the sorbent bed increased the CO2 capture capacity, and no marked difference could be detected in CO2 capture capacity in the temperature range of 250–300 ℃, but it decreased slightly at 320 ℃. As shown in Fig. 10(d, e), in the cyclic stability test, under pure CO2 sorption conditions (first 5 cycles), CO2 capture and CH4 production performance were higher, while under sorption conditions of simulated flue gas composition containing 4.5 % O2 (6–10 cycles), the performance decreased. Although the performance is reduced, it is still better than other reported DFMs. Under O2-free conditions, the CO2 capture capacity of HT-46Ni material reaches 1.76 mol/kg DFM, and the CH4 productivity is 0.98 mol/kg DFM, which is significantly improved compared with other reported DFM. Dewoolkar et al. prepared bifunctional materials (Ni-HTC or HM1, Ni-CaO/Al2O3 or HM2) [224]. The results show that the CH4 conversion rate and hydrogen production rate of HM1 and HM2 are higher than the mixture of catalyst and sorbent. This is due to the fact that there is no diffusion limitation in the hybrid material, and it has better sorption characteristics and longer breakthrough time. HM1 has a breakthrough time of 15 min and the capture capacity of 0.9 mol CO2/kg sorbent. They also studied the preparation of hydrotalcite-based hybrid materials (Ni-MgHTlc, Ni-CaHTlc, Ni-CuHTlc and Ni-ZnHTlc) modified with four different cations (Mg2+, Ca2+, Cu2+ and Zn2+). Ni-CuHTlc showed the highest conversion (96.4 %) at 773 K, which was attributed to Cu promoting the rapid endothermic dehydrogenation reaction of ethanol and enhancing material stability. Moreover, the sorption capacity of Ni-CuHTlc is higher than that of Ni-MgHTlc, which is related to the higher activity of Ni-Cu alloy in enhancing hydrogen production and the high surface area of Ni-CuHTlc. In the multi-cycle performance test of 25 cycles, Ni-CuHTlc and Ni-MgHTlc showed high stability to 21 and 18 cycles respectively, and the H2 purity remained above 90 % throughout. Halabi et al. used the Rh/Ce2Zr1− a O2 catalyst to explore the applicability of K-promoted hydrotalcite binding for pure H2 production [215]. The results showed that under slow sorption kinetics, the maximum CH4 conversion of low-capacity (0.65 mol/kg) and high-capacity (5 mol/kg) sorbents was almost the same (about 88 %), but under fast sorption kinetics, the high-capacity sorbent could further improve the conversion rate, even to 100 %. Ghungrud et al. synthesized a new bifunctional material composed of Ni, Co (in different proportions) and hydrotalcite (HTlc) [231]. It was found that Ni10Co30/HTlc (HM1) and Ni10Co30/HTlc (HM2) had higher H2 yields, which were attributed to the promoting effect of Co content on the WGS reaction. Qi et al. physically mixed the commercial CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst with the K2CO3-promoted hydrotalcite [226]. When the reaction temperature was 533 K, the methanol/water molar ratio was 3, and the methanol space velocity was 9.5 × 103 h−1, a high-purity H2 stream (CO content less than 0.1 %) was obtained by SESRE, and the methanol conversion rate reached 90 %. In the initial stage of the reaction, the sorption of CO2 by K-hydrotalcite significantly enhanced the SRE reaction, but as the reaction proceeded, the sorption rate of the sorbent slowed down due to the diffusion resistance within the particles. After about 1 h, the CO2 sorption reached saturation, and the reaction transformed into traditional SRE. Cunha et al. synthesized a bifunctional K-Ni-Cu-hydrotalcite hybrid material for SESRE hydrogen production [232]. In terms of catalytic performance, Cu has a preference for catalyzing ethanol dehydrogenation and WGS reactions, while Ni is better suited for acetaldehyde decomposition and methane steam reforming reactions. At 773 K and a water/ethanol molar ratio of 10, the hybrid material can obtain a high-purity hydrogen flow (99.8 mol%, dry basis) during the pre-penetration period, and the hydrogen concentration drops to 67.1 mol% after penetration. Dewoolkar et al. prepared the unpromoted hybrid material HM1 (Cu-based hydrotalcite combined with Ni), and promoted it with Pt and Ru to obtain Pt-HM1 and Ru-HM1 [233]. In the ethylene glycol SESR reaction, the increase in temperature promoted the conversion of ethylene glycol. At 873 K, the conversion rate of all hybrid materials was the highest, and the conversion rate of Pt-HM1 reached 97.3 %, which was higher than that of Ru-HM1 (91.4 %) and HM1 (75.3 %). This was attributed to the higher surface area of Pt-HM1 providing more active sites. After 25 cycles of sorption-regeneration experiments, the hybrid materials showed good stability. HM1 was stable for 8 cycles, Pt-HM1 for 16 cycles, and Ru-HM1 for up to 22 cycles, which was due to factors such as effective metal-support interaction, high metal dispersion and strong sorption performance. Ghungrud et al. modified hydrotalcite with calcium, copper and zinc to prepare new bifunctional materials (Co-Ca-HTlc, Co-Cu-HTlc and Co-Zn-HTlc) for SESRG hydrogen production [225]. At 773 K, the glycerol conversion of Co-Ca-HTlc (HM1) reached a maximum of 90.4 %, while at 823 K, Co-Cu-HTlc (HM2) and Co-Zn-HTlc (HM3) reached higher conversions of 92.8 % and 81.4 %, respectively. In terms of product gas composition, as the temperature rose, there was an upward trend in the H2 content and a downward trend in the CO2 and CH4 contents, which was attributed to the fact that methane reforming and reverse WGS reactions were more favorable at high temperatures. In the SESR reaction with hydrotalcite as an sorbent, the catalyst is crucial to improving reaction performance and promoting efficient hydrogen production. Existing studies have shown that different types of catalysts combined with hydrotalcite can significantly improve hydrogen purity, reactant conversion rate and carbon dioxide sorption capacity. For example, bifunctional materials formed by Ni-based, Co-based and other catalysts and hydrotalcite show good performance under different reaction conditions. Notably, there is a lack of literature exploring hydrotalcite sorbent bifunctional materials for biomass sorption-enhanced reforming to produce hydrogen, hindering practical discussions on their performance in real biomass applications—especially regarding how hydrotalcite's anionic structure interacts with biomass ash and whether catalyst-sorbent synergies can mitigate sintering or impurity-induced deactivation. Future research can focus on the following two aspects: first, further explore new catalyst systems by combining multiple active components and promoters (e.g., alkali metals or rare earth oxides) to achieve higher catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability, with specific attention to their tolerance toward biomass-derived impurities (such as chlorine or silica). Second, conduct in-depth studies on the synergistic mechanism between catalysts and hydrotalcite sorbents, optimizing material structures and compositions (e.g., adjusting metal ion ratios in hydrotalcite layers or modifying catalyst support interfaces) to enhance both sorption kinetics and catalytic efficiency during the reaction. Such efforts should also prioritize evaluating bifunctional materials in real biomass SESR systems, including their long-term resistance to ash erosion and cyclic stability with actual biomass feedstocks, to bridge the gap toward practical large-scale hydrogen production. 6 The combination of sorption-enhanced technology and other technologies 6.1 Sorption-enhanced chemical looping reforming (SE-CLR) Sorption-enhanced chemical looping reforming (SE-CLR) is an innovative technology that combines sorbents with a chemical looping reforming (CLR) process, as shown in Fig. 11 (a) [18]. It has significant advantages in hydrogen production and CO2 capture [234–236]. Sorbents play a vital role in SE-CLR technology. They can capture CO2 generated during the reaction in situ, breaking the constraints of chemical equilibrium, thereby significantly improving the production and purity of hydrogen. The gaseous products decomposed from biomass feedstock materials undergo a redox reaction with the oxygen carrier. The oxygen carrier provides lattice oxygen to partially oxidize the gaseous products, and at the same time, it is reduced to a catalyst. Since the heat released by the redox reaction during the reaction can be partially or fully used to compensate for the heat required for endothermic processes such as reforming reactions, SE-CLR technology can achieve a thermal balance of the system without adding a large amount of additional heat sources. This not only reduces energy consumption but also reduces dependence on external energy supplies and improves the energy efficiency of the entire system. As a key component of this technology, the oxygen carrier occupies a crucial position in improving the performance of the hydrogen production process. Common metal oxygen carriers include NiO, Fe2O3, CuO and Co3O4. 6.1.1 Ni-based oxygen carrier Ni-based oxygen carrier has strong catalytic properties and perform well in SE-CLR systems [237]. Wang et al. used NiO/Al2O3 as the oxygen carrier and CaO as the sorbent to study the SE-CLR of hydrogen for glycerol [238]. High purity hydrogen (>95 %) is obtained in the initial stage at 800 K and 1 atm. Under optimized conditions (pressure 1–20 atm, temperature 800 K, oxygen excess coefficient 1, sorbent excess coefficient 1), high hydrogen production rate and thermal efficiency can be achieved. Dou et al. used NiO/Al2O3 oxygen carriers and CaO-based sorbents to explore the SE-CLR of ethanol for hydrogen production [239]. The temperature was set to 600 ℃, the pressure was 1.0 atm, and the steam to carbon molar ratio (S/C) was 3.0. When the Ca/Ni molar ratio is 3.0, the hydrogen selectivity and feed conversion reach the highest, the hydrogen production increases, and the CO and CO2 concentrations decrease significantly. However, an excessively high Ca/Ni ratio will cause the OC particles to be surrounded by the sorbent, inhibiting hydrogen production. Antzaras et al. explored the influence of the type of oxidant on the reaction of NiO/ZrO2 oxygen carrier during the regeneration stage [240]. Using pure O2 as oxidant, up to 47 % autothermal regeneration can be achieved at lower space velocities (GHSV = 750 h−1), approaching 83 % of the theoretical maximum. However, compared with experiments using air as the oxidant, the material's cyclic stability was poor when using pure O2. This is because the sorbent is exposed to high temperature and high CO2 partial pressure for a long time, resulting in severe sintering, which reduces the calcination rate and aggravates the thermal coupling effect. Zhang et al. integrated the CaO sorbent with the NiO/NiAl2O4 catalyst to prepare a bifunctional Ni-based composite oxygen carrier (NCA) and compared it with a traditional physically Ni-based mixed oxygen carrier (NAC) [19]. The results show that compared with NAC, NCA has a more uniform element distribution, stronger reducing ability, shorter ‘dead time’, stronger CO2 sorption capacity, higher H2 production efficiency, and better ethanol conversion rate. During a 20-cycle test, the CO2 sorption capacity and H2 concentration of NCA remained stable, while the H2 concentration of NAC dropped significantly due to the deterioration of sorption performance. Antzaras et al. developed bifunctional hybrid catalytic materials based on NiO and CaO for the sorption-enhanced chemical looping steam methane reforming (SE-CL-SMR) process [241], as depicted in Fig. 11(b). Results showed that all developed materials achieved high CH4 conversion, producing high-purity hydrogen (>95 %) at 650 ℃ and a steam/carbon ratio of 3. Compared with the mechanically mixed sorbents and oxygen transfer materials (OTMs), the bifunctional materials are able to more efficiently utilize the heat generated by Ni reoxidation during the regeneration process due to the direct heat transfer between the OTM and sorbent phases. Xu et al. investigated the role of NiO/dolomite in the chemical looping reforming reaction of biomass pyrolysis oil at different temperatures [242]. Biomass pyrolysis oil (BPO) conversion is mainly dominated by sorption enhancement and catalytic reforming; at high temperatures (800, 900 and 1000 ℃), it mainly acts as an oxygen carrier and catalyst, and the BPO conversion is controlled by the synergistic effect of lattice oxygen and catalysis. Under the conditions of 900 ℃ and an oxygen coefficient (ϕ) of 0.4, the cold gas efficiency (CGE) and syngas production decreased slightly after 10 cycles, indicating that NiO/dolomite has good cycle performance under this condition. Omoniyi et al. studied the cyclic stability of NiO/calcium aluminate as a bed material in the acetic acid SE-CLR hydrogen production process [243]. The acetic acid conversion exceeded 80 % and the hydrogen production efficiency exceeded 78 % of the equilibrium value in all 20 SE-CLR cycles at 650 ℃. Zeng et al. used NiO/MgAl2O4 oxygen carrier and CaO sorbent to enhance the sorption of ethanol and study hydrogen production by CLR [18]. The stability experiment found that owing to the inevitable sintering and carbon deposition of oxygen carriers (OCs), the hydrogen production and selectivity dropped from 207 mmol to 174 mmol, and the H2 purity dropped from 95 % to 85 %. In the improved stability SE-CLR experiment, obtained stable hydrogen production with a purity of 89 %–87 % and a selectivity of 96 %–93 %. Liu et al. prepared a Li-based sorbent and a Ni-based oxygen carrier for SE-CL-SMR [244], as shown in Fig. 11(c). The study found that the Li-based sorbent can promote the forward shift of the CL-SMR reaction equilibrium and improve the CH4 conversion rate and H2 purity, and indirectly enhanced hydrogen production. The sorbent reduces the apparent activation energy of the reaction. Under optimal conditions, the performance of the oxygen carrier and sorbent particles did not decrease after 10 cycles. After the reaction, their crystal structure, physical form, and element distribution remained basically unchanged, and they had high cyclic stability. Numerous studies have shown that NiO oxygen carriers can improve reaction performance in many aspects in SE-CLR reactions. When combined with different sorbents, H2 purity, selectivity, and feed conversion can be significantly improved. Although the current research on Ni-based oxygen carriers in SE-CLR systems has achieved certain results, there are still many aspects that need further exploration. In terms of material performance optimization, in-depth research can be conducted on how to further improve the anti-sintering and anti-carbon deposition properties of Ni-based oxygen carriers and sorbents to improve long-term cyclic stability, such as by improving the preparation process or adding new additives. For different reaction systems and working conditions, it is necessary to more comprehensively explore the optimal combination and operating conditions of Ni-based oxygen carriers and sorbents to achieve higher reaction efficiency and product purity. At the same time, strengthening the in-depth understanding of the reaction mechanism, especially the microscopic reaction mechanism under complex reaction environments, will help provide a more solid theoretical foundation for material design and reaction optimization. In addition, considering partical industrial applications, it is necessary to evaluate the cost-effectiveness and equipment compatibility of these materials and reaction systems in large-scale production to promote SE-CLR technology from the laboratory to industrial applications. 6.1.2 Fe-based oxygen carrier In the SE-CLR reaction, iron oxygen carriers play a vital role [245]. Fe-based oxygen carriers have the advantages of low cost, high chemical stability, non-toxicity, low sintering temperature, and difficulty in fluidization, and researchers have conducted extensive research. Hafizi et al. used 22Fe2O3/MgAl2O4 and 22Fe2O3/Al2O3 as oxygen carriers and Ce-promoted CaO as a CO2 absorbent [246]. The Ce-promoted CaO absorbent showed high CO2 sorption activity, and the synergistic effect of the two improved the hydrogen production performance. In nine SE-CLR cycles, the MgAl2O4 carrier and Ce/Ca absorbent showed high activity, indicating that the system composed of the iron oxide carrier and absorbent has good stability in multiple cycles and can continuously and stably produce high-purity hydrogen. Saupsor et al. prepared Fe2O3/CaO-Al2O3 bifunctional catalysts by different methods (sol–gel method, mechanical mixing method and impregnation method) for ethanol SE-CLR hydrogen production [247]. Preparation methods influence catalyst phase composition and performance. Sol-gel promotes Fe-Ca interaction to form Ca2Fe2O5, optimized by iron addition steps. Mechanical mixing inhibits Ca2Fe2O5 but causes iron densification with minimal surface area. Impregnation method excels due to Ca12Al14O33 and Ca2Fe2O5, enhancing CaO sorption and Fe2O3 oxygen-carrier capacity in steam oxidation. Fernández et al. proposed a method to produce hydrogen and capture CO2 by combining SER with iron oxide chemical looping [248]. In the SER-CLC process, methane is reformed in the SER stage at 670 ℃. Compared with traditional steam methane reforming (SMR), this process achieves higher hydrogen production efficiency at lower temperatures. This is due to the cyclic effect of the iron oxide carrier in the reaction system and the synergistic cooperation with the sorbent (CaO), which enables the reaction to proceed efficiently, improves the purity of hydrogen and achieves effective capture of CO2. Zhao et al. synthesized a Ca-Fe-Mg bifunctional material derived from layered double hydroxide (LDH) [249], and its reaction process is shown in Fig. 11(d). In terms of cyclic stability, the material showed some stability in 5 chemical looping reforming cycles, but there was also a decrease in activity, mainly due to factors such as the transformation of the Ca2Fe2O5 phase to the MgFe2O4 phase, crystal size change and particle agglomeration. The iron oxide carriers in the above studies all presented a positive impact on the reaction performance in the SE-CLR reaction. They can all participate in the redox process of the fuel, promote the reaction by providing lattice oxygen, and synergize with the CO2 absorber to varying degrees to increase the yield and purity of hydrogen, while enhancing the capture efficiency of CO2. Future research can further explore the synergistic mechanism of Fe-based oxygen carriers and different sorbents, and further optimize the combination of the two to improve reaction efficiency and product purity. For the problem of activity decay of existing materials during the cycle, it is necessary to study more effective modification methods to inhibit adverse changes such as phase transition and particle agglomeration, and enhance the cyclic stability of materials. At the same time, it is necessary to explore new preparation processes, accurately control the microstructure and phase composition of materials, and thus develop Fe-based oxygen carriers and bifunctional materials with better performance. 6.1.3 Cu-based oxygen carrier Cu-based oxygen carriers have the advantages of strong oxygen transport capacity, high activity, moderate cost, and insensitivity to sulfur-containing impurities. Martini et al. simulated the Ca-Cu cycle process using a one-dimensional pseudo-homogeneous model (PHM) and a simplified model (based on the sharp front method) [250]. In SER, 15 wt% CaO in the bed yields 95 % H2 with minimal low-purity H2 loss in the first step. In continuous Cu oxidation, the recycling product gas introduces small CO2 to minimize calcination CO2 loss. In solid regeneration, the Cu/Ca ratio is fuel-gas determined for energy-neutral reaction. The process achieves 71–74 % thermal efficiency and ∼80 % carbon capture efficiency. Ma et al. prepared the core–shell structured CaO-CuO/MgO@Al2O3 material (CCMA) using the self-assembly template synthesis (SATS) technology [251]. In 30-cycle tests, CCMA exhibited the highest and most stable CO2 absorption (0.08 g CO2/g), nearing the theoretical value with no decline. During calcination-reduction, CaO is fully regenerated via CaCO3 decomposition, while CuO-methane exotherm compensates for CaCO3 calcination heat, achieving thermal neutrality. In oxidation, reduced CCMA shows 97 %–98 % Cu conversion. After the cycle, CCMA resists sintering, with 1.4 N crushing strength meeting fluidization needs. Martini et al. used a Cu-based material (65 wt% Cu on Al2O3) developed by Johnson Matthey PLC as an oxygen carrier in the experiment to verify the concept of the Ca-Cu cycle process [252]. In SER, an increase in pressure had a negative impact on the step, reducing the purity of hydrogen in the outlet gas stream, while the S/C ratio did not affect the average outlet hydrogen fraction. In the oxidation step, increasing the oxygen concentration in the feed increased CO2 evolution, while increasing the pressure reduced it. In the regeneration step, increasing the hydrogen fraction in the feed increased the amount of sorbent that could be regenerated, with 70 wt% of the sorbent in the bed being regenerated at 60 vol% hydrogen in the feed. The solids retained good chemical properties after more than 285 complete cycles, and the results were reproducible. The research on Cu-based oxygen carriers in related cycle processes has achieved certain results, but there are still many aspects worth exploring in the future. On the one hand, the operating conditions and material formulations of the Ca-Cu cycle process can be further optimized, and the reaction mechanisms of each step under different working conditions can be studied more deeply to improve the overall reaction efficiency and carbon capture capacity. On the other hand, in response to the performance degradation problem of existing materials in the long-term cycle process, more effective modification methods should be developed to enhance the stability and durability of the materials. 6.1.4 Co3O4-based oxygen carrier Co3O4-based oxygen carriers often exhibit high catalytic activity and can effectively activate reactant molecules in chemical looping reforming reactions. Akbari-Emadabadi et al. synthesized Ca-mCo (m is the calcium-cobalt mass ratio) and Ca-mCo-nY (n is the calcium-yttrium mass ratio) bifunctional catalysts/sorbents by coprecipitation [253]. In the CL-SMR process, CH4 conversion and H2 yield increased with rising reduction temperature, and first rose then fell with increasing Ca-Co mass ratio. Ca-9Co showed the highest CH4 conversion (94.9 %) and H2 yield (81.5 %) at 700 ℃, with an average H2/CO molar ratio of 5.2. Among Ca-9Co samples at different temperatures, Ca-9Co-4.5Y exhibited the highest activity. In isothermal reduction-calcination/oxidation cycles, Ca-9Co-18Y performed poorly, while catalyst/sorbent performance improved with increasing Y content. Ca-9Co-4.5Y performed best, with a H2/CO molar ratio and a CO2 volume percentage in the calcination/oxidation step of approximately 5.3 and 6.9, respectively. Li et al. prepared Pt-doped and undoped calcium cobalt oxide (CCO) [164]. When fresh CCO or Pt/CCO reacted with CH4, initial CH4 conversion reached about 80 %, then declined before full conversion. Pt doping shortened the low-conversion period: from the 3rd cycle, CH4 fully converted within <8 min. In 20-cycle tests, Pt/CCO's CLMC-stage average CH4 conversion rose from 7.8 % to 78.1 % in the first 6 cycles, stabilizing at about 70 % with CO2 selectivity >90 %. In SESRG, pre-breakthrough H2 mole fraction increased from 90.2 % to 95.0 % in 3 cycles, stabilizing at about 96 %. Hafizi et al. prepared Co3O4/SiO2 oxygen carriers by incipient wetness impregnation and synthesized Ca-based sorbents with different Ce contents by co-precipitation [254]. In the SE-CL-SMR process, the Co3O4/SiO2 oxygen carrier was mixed with different sorbents for testing. At 550 ℃, the sorbent combinations of Ca/Ce = 0.94/0.06 and Ca/Ce = 0.91/0.09 made the H2 purity reach about 95 %, which was higher than the CLR process (about 84 %), and the amount of residual methane was reduced. In the future, researchers can further study its catalytic mechanism in more complex reaction systems, clarify the synergistic effect principle between various elements, and further optimize the composition and structure of Co-based oxygen carriers/sorbents to improve their catalytic activity and selectivity. For different reaction conditions and raw materials, explore the best process parameters to maximize the reaction efficiency and product quality. In addition, it is necessary to strengthen the research on the stability of materials during long-term cyclic use, develop effective modification methods such as anti-sintering and anti-carbon deposition, and extend the service life of materials. 6.1.5 Bimetallic oxygen carriers Bimetallic oxygen carriers are usually composed of a combination of two different metal oxides, aiming to combine the advantages of each component and improve the performance of the oxygen carrier. Tan et al. synthesized NiO/CuO composites with different CuO contents and conducted experiments in a fixed-bed reactor [255]. Experimental results show that the presence of CuO hinders the activity of Ni-based catalysts in hydrogen production, and this hindering effect increases with the increase in CuO content and calcination temperature. Bimetallic CuO-NiO-based bifunctional materials were developed by Nimmas et al. [256]. The study found that the addition of CuO has a positive impact on hydrogen production performance and can reduce the reforming temperature, and the position of CuO in the bifunctional material has a significant impact. The NiO-CuO-CaO-Ca12Al14O33 material synthesized by the sol–gel one-step method can produce 91 % H2 purity in 60 min. At the same time, the presence of CuO can reduce the regeneration temperature of CaO. Papalas et al. used a sol–gel autocombustion method to synthesize an oxygen carrier containing 40 wt% Ni and Co-based oxides and 60 wt% ZrO2 [257]. In the hydrogen production stage, the reduced bimetallic oxygen carrier has similar catalytic behavior to the monometallic oxygen carrier. It can produce about 0.98 mmol H2/min/g of reduced OC at 650 ℃. The H2 purity is about 94 % and the yield is about 90 %. During the calcination/oxidation stage, the oxidation energy of the bimetallic oxygen carrier covers 42 % more of the calcination energy requirement than that of the monometallic Ni-based oxygen carrier (the degree of self-heating is 40.6 % for the bimetallic oxygen carrier and 28.6 % for the monometallic). Through characterization, it was found that the addition of Co changed the oxidation mechanism and made the bimetallic material oxidize faster. This is because Co segregates on the outer wall of the oxide shell during the oxidation process, forming pinholes, which promotes the penetration of oxygen molecules and accelerates the oxidation of the material. Zhong et al. designed and used Ni-doped Ca2Fe2O5 perovskite as an oxygen carrier and CO2 sorbent [258]. In the fuel reactor (FR), CaO captures CO2 in situ, improving syngas yield and PET conversion. When 25 % CaO (Ca2Ni0.75Fe1.25O5-0.25CaO) is added, the synthesis gas purity increases to 82.71 %, the H2 production increases to 8.01 mmol/g OC, and the purity is 93.26 %. They proposed the reaction mechanism of Ca2Fe x Ni2− x O5/NiO/CaO oxygen carrier and sorbent in the sorption-enhanced chemical looping reforming coupled with water splitting (SE-CLR-WS) process, as shown in Fig. 11(e). In the SE-CLR-WS process, PET and steam reforming gas in the FR stage react with NiO and Ca2Fe x Ni2− x O5 to generate various gases, CO2 is captured by CaO to obtain high-purity syngas, and Ni enhances the lattice oxygen activity to promote the reaction. The CR stage achieves CO2 desorption, carbon deposit elimination, CaO regeneration and CO2 collection to improve H2 purity. In the SR stage, steam oxidation deeply reduced OCs generates H2 and regenerates them. This is due to the deep reduction of OCs in FR and the removal of carbon deposits by CR, which ensures the purity and output of H2. Powell et al. used Aspen Plus software to conduct modeling and thermodynamic analysis of the SE-CL-SMR process [259]. The results show that the introduction of CaO can reduce carbon deposits, and the increase in metal oxide and steam can improve hydrogen production and purity. The presence of CuO allows the reforming reactor to operate under adiabatic conditions of 600–700 ℃, and increasing NiO:CuO ratio increases CH4 conversion. Under certain operating conditions, H2 purity is predicted to reach 98 %, with minimal CO2 production and a thermal efficiency of approximately 86 %. Liu et al. proposed an isothermal SE-CLR process, using Fe-Ni bimetallic oxide particles as oxygen carriers for SMR and K2CO3-promoted Li4SiO4 particles as CO2 absorbers [198]. The results show that when the mass ratio of optimized absorbent to metal oxide is 7:4, the H2 purity can be increased to 92 % and the CO2 absorption rate can reach 95 %. After 25 cycle experiments at 600 ℃ and 1 bar, the H2 purity stabilized at 90.1 % ± 1.2 % and the CO2 absorption rate stabilized at 92.5 % ± 1.5 %. Research on bimetallic oxygen carriers has made significant progress in improving hydrogen production and purity, reducing reaction temperature, improving energy utilization efficiency, and expanding the application range of feedstocks. Despite this, there are still many aspects to be explored in the research of bimetallic oxygen carriers. On the one hand, the interaction mechanism between the components of bimetallic oxygen carriers in different studies has not been fully clarified, and the follow-up should focus on this to provide a more accurate theoretical basis for material design. On the other hand, existing research is mostly concentrated under laboratory conditions, and it is necessary to strengthen research on its long-term stability and adaptability under partical complex working conditions, and explore how to improve the material's resistance to impurities, sintering, and carbon deposition. In addition, in terms of material preparation technology, more efficient and low-cost synthesis methods can be developed to achieve large-scale industrial production. In summary, SE-CLR technology has significant advantages in hydrogen production and CO2 capture, and various oxygen carriers play a key role in this. Ni-based oxygen carriers have strong catalytic performance and can improve various aspects of reaction performance when combined with different sorbents, but the synergistic mechanism with new sorbents needs to be explored; Fe-based oxygen carriers have low cost and good stability, and can cooperate with sorbents to produce hydrogen, and show good cyclic stability after optimization; Cu-based oxygen carriers have good oxygen transport capacity, moderate cost, and can achieve high thermal efficiency and carbon capture efficiency; Co-based oxygen carriers have high catalytic activity and great potential in chemical looping reactions; bimetallic oxygen carriers combine the advantages of multiple metals and have achieved remarkable results in hydrogen production and in lowering reaction temperature. Future research should further explore the synergistic mechanism of different oxygen carriers and sorbents, optimize the metal combination and ratio of bimetallic oxygen carriers, develop more efficient and stable oxygen carrier-sorbent systems, and promote the widespread application of SE-CLR technology in the energy field. 6.2 Sorption-enhanced and dry reforming of methane (SE-DRM) During the reforming process, sorption enhancement can capture CO2 by forming carbonates. To ensure continuous hydrogen production, the carbonates must be decarbonized in the regeneration step so that the regenerated sorbent can be recycled and the removed CO2 can be reused or stored. Methane, as a greenhouse gas, can be coupled to carbonate decomposition, whereby dry reforming of methane (DRM) can occur in situ on the carbonate surface [260–262]. However, it is important to note that carbonate decomposition often requires high temperatures of more than 800 ℃ and consumes a lot of heat, generating waste heat. Despite this, it is worth mentioning that this waste heat can drive the sorption-enhanced coupled DRM reaction [201,263–265], making the entire reaction process operate without the need for additional energy input. In this reaction, the carbon utilization cycle can be established by simply reacting methane with the CO2 produced by the decomposition of CaCO3 to generate CO and H2. Studies have shown that when CaCO3 is calcined in a reducing gas (such as CH4), it can not only reduce its decomposition temperature but also increase the conversion rate of CO2. Dang et al. prepared a series of 10Ni-xPd-CA2.8 catalysts (x is the mass fraction of the noble metal Pd) by co-precipitation for the integrated process of SESR reaction and methane reforming (MR) [163], as shown in Fig. 12 (a). After 10 SESR-MR cycles, the catalyst showed good stability, with the Ni particle size increasing by only 8 % and the sorption enhancement effect decreasing by only 25 %. In the ten-cycle tests, a total of 98.3 % hydrogen-rich gas flow and synthesis gas with H2/CO < 3 were produced. Hu et al. synthesized a bifunctional material (NiCe/Ca@Zr) composed of Ni and CeO2 nanoparticles co-loaded on ZrO2-coated CaCO3 for calcium cyclic dry reforming of methane (CaL@DRM) [266]. In the CaL@DRM cycle reaction, the two materials can still maintain a certain activity after 25 cycles under the thermodynamically unfavorable conditions of 5 vol% CO2 feed concentration (close to real flue gas) and 720 ℃. The CH4 conversion rate and H2 production of NiCe/Ca@Zr are higher in the initial stage of the reaction, and its resistance to carbon deposition is stronger, with the amount of carbon deposition significantly less than that of Ni/Ca@Zr. Lee et al. developed Ru-doped Sr0.92Y0.08TiO3 perovskite catalysts and applied them to an integrated system of DRM and SEWGS reactions [267]. In the integrated system, by optimizing the reaction conditions (DRM reaction temperature of 800 ℃, CO2/CH4 ratio of 3; WGS reaction temperature of 300 ℃, steam/CO ratio of 2.26), the system can produce high-purity H2 (>99.5 %) directly from CH4/CO2 mixed gas, and it shows good stability in cyclic operation. After three cycles of testing, it can still maintain a high H2 purity. The duration of high-purity H2 production in the second cycle is shortened to about 6 min, and the third cycle can still maintain good performance. Zhang et al. used Aspen Plus to thermodynamically simulate the process to evaluate the overall performance of the biomass integrated sorption-enhanced graded gasification and in situ CO2 utilization (SESG-in situ MR) process based on the calcium cycle [34], as shown in Fig. 12(b). Under the operating conditions of S/B = 1.4, T sr = 600 ℃, CaO/B = 6.5, T mr = 800 °C, and CH4/B = 0.5, the carbon conversion rate of the SESG-in situ MR process is as high as 93.87 %, the H2 and CO production are 3.038 and 1.473 Nm3/kg biomass, respectively, and the H2/CO ratio is 2.06, which is suitable for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. Compared with the SESG+MR and SESG processes, the SESG-in situ MR process has higher energy conversion efficiency (74.5 %) and exergy efficiency (68.6 %), CO2 emissions are reduced by 73.5 %, and CO2 utilization is increased by 135 %. The above research has made significant progress in the field of sorption-enhanced coupled DRM reaction through the design of catalysts, optimization of reaction conditions, and integration of processes. Future research can strengthen the study of the reaction mechanism and the reaction kinetics of SE-DRM, which will help to deeply understand the mechanism of action of the catalyst and provide theoretical guidance for the design and optimization of the catalyst. It is necessary to further optimize the integrated process of the reaction process, solve the coupling problem between reactions, and improve the overall performance and stability of the system. 6.3 Sorption-enhanced and solid oxide fuel cells (SE-SOFC) Fuel cells have great application prospects in the field of hydrogen Energy Technol.. They can cleanly and efficiently convert the chemical energy of hydrogen into electrical energy without negative environmental impact. Solid oxide fuel cells (SOFC), as one of them, have developed rapidly in the past few decades since Nernst first studied them in 1899 [268–270]. With an operating temperature as high as ranging from 873 to 1273 K, they are highly fitting for stationary combined heat and power (CHP) systems in industrial settings. In the past few years, a substantial number of studies have focused on integrating solid fuel utilization technology with SOFC. For instance, the integrated coal gasification fuel cell combined cycle (IGFC), which is a power generation system utilizing coal as the gasification feedstock, converts coal-based power generation from a thermodynamic process into an electrochemical one, thus considerably enhancing the energy generation efficiency. However, the non-renewable nature of fossil fuels such as coal poses challenges, and employing renewable fuels like biomass as well as biomass-derived chemicals and gases represents a possible solution for environmental issues. SOFC power generation system technology is widely applicable to fuel types. Fuels such as hydrogen, natural gas, methanol, glycerol, ethanol, n-butanol, bio-oil, and biomass all perform well in the system, but high-carbon fuels need to be reformed externally into small molecule synthesis gas to avoid carbon deposition, and the product gases with a high level of CO2 content can corrode the cathode and lead to the shifting of the reforming reaction equilibrium to the left, reducing battery efficiency. To this end, researchers combined SER technology with the SOFC process based on Le Chatelier's principle, removing CO2 through sorbents and catalysts to change the reforming reaction equilibrium limit and improve H2 purity and yield [271,272]. Wang et al. studied the chemical looping gasification (CLG) of coal fuel and the SOFC integrated system (SE-CLG-SOFC), introducing chemical looping and CO2 sorption technology [273]. It was found that adding oxygen carriers and sorbents can increase SOFC output power, but will increase exergy losses. The exergy efficiency of most modules in the system can reach 80 % (except for the tar separation module). Increasing the amount of gasification agents (H2O/C) is beneficial to the energy performance of the system. When the H2O/C molar ratio increases to 3.0, the exergy efficiency of SOFC can reach 97 %. Wiranarongkorn et al. studied the integrated process of bio-oil Ca-looping SESR and SOFC [274]. Acetic acid was taken as a model compound for the water phase of bio-oil, and simulations discovered that the system efficiency of the integrated process was able to reach 42.33 % under the optimal conditions of 600 ℃, S/F = 5, CaO/fuel = 2, SOFC temperature of 800 ℃ and fuel utilization of 0.85. Compared with traditional processes, its hydrogen production, purity, electrical efficiency and carbon formation are better, for example, the hydrogen concentration is increased from 33.67 % of the traditional process to 48.7 %. Moreover, a simulation of a 40-unit SOFC stack integrated with a bio-oil sorption-enhanced steam reformer was conducted by them [275]. The results showed that as the air–fuel ratio and steam-fuel ratio went up, the average stack temperature as well as the temperature gradient declined. However, the reduction in stack temperature would lead to a decrease in the system efficiency. Meanwhile, an increase in the bio-oil flow rate would lower the system efficiency and wasn't beneficial for reducing the maximum temperature gradient. They conducted an economic feasibility analysis on the bio-oil SESR and SOFC integrated system (160 kW AC power production) [276]. The net present value and levelized cost of energy of different configuration systems (such as SESR-SOFC system with or without anode gas recirculation and traditional reforming-based SOFC system) were compared. The results show that although the SESR-SOFC system with anode gas recirculation is superior, it is still necessary to reduce the SOFC capital cost, interest rate, and bio-oil cost, or increase carbon tax, feed-in tariff (FiT) and other measures to improve its economic feasibility. Considering a carbon tax of $50/ton of CO2, the system can be equivalent to a traditional CHP system in the 14th year; increasing the FiT by 20 % can reduce the system NPC by 39.6 %. Diglio et al. studied the CaO/CuO/NiO SE-SMR and SOFC integrated system [277], as shown in Fig. 12(c). The system is divided into three stages. By optimizing the operating conditions of each stage, the CH4 conversion rate is about 95 %, the H2 yield is about 3.2 mol/mol, and the H2 purity is about 90 %. A high-concentration CO2 stream can be obtained to achieve near-zero CO2 emissions. Compared with the traditional system, its net electrical efficiency and thermal efficiency are 56 % and 30 % respectively, and the overall efficiency is 86 %, which has better thermodynamic, environmental and economic performance. Jiang et al. used Ni/Al2O3-SiC as a catalyst and Co x Mg y Ca(1− x − y )O z as an sorbent to study the partial oxidation of propane to produce hydrogen for SOFC [278]. It was found that Co0.110Mg0.204Ca0.686O2 sorbent has uniform pore size distribution and high CO2 sorption capacity (33 wt%, more than 4 times higher than CaO powder). At 700 ℃, the sorbent mixed with the catalyst increased hydrogen production by 41.54 %, reduced outlet CO and CO2 content. The sorbent performance was stable after 25 cycles, with a maximum output power density of 513 mW/cm2 (equivalent to 160 mL/min pure H2) in the SOFC test system, as shown in Fig. 12(d). In conclusion, coupling sorption enhancement technology with SOFC has achieved certain results in various fuel systems. By introducing chemical looping and CO2 sorption technology, the output power, hydrogen purity and yield of SOFC have been effectively improved, the system efficiency has been improved, and good thermodynamic, environmental and economic performance has been shown. In the future, research in this field should focus on improving the long-term stability of the coupled system, and solve problems such as material aging and performance degradation through in-depth research on material properties and reaction mechanisms. It is necessary to further optimize the operating conditions of the system, including temperature, pressure, fuel-to-gas ratio, etc., to achieve more efficient energy conversion. At the same time, explore ways to reduce costs, such as developing low-cost, high-performance sorbents and catalysts, so as to promote the widespread application of this technology in the energy field. 7 Conclusions and prospects SESR technology is based on chemical equilibrium and sorption principles and shows unique advantages in the process of using biomass synthesis gas to produce hydrogen. The solid sorbent selectively captures CO2 and pushes the reforming reaction balance toward the direction of hydrogen production, effectively improving the production and purity of hydrogen. This not only reduces the need for downstream separation processes, reduces costs and energy consumption, but also provides assistance for the capture and storage of CO2. This article systematically explains the effects of biomass feedstock material characteristics and operating parameters on SESR reaction. The chemical composition, ash and moisture content of the feedstocks affect the reaction process, product distribution and energy conversion efficiency. Among the operating parameters, the gasification temperature and S/F are crucial. The temperature affects the content of hydrogen and other products and the related conditions of the products. The material ratio has a significant effect on many aspects such as hydrogen production and needs to be precisely controlled. Meanwhile, the research progress of composite bifunctional materials comprising sorbents (Ca-based, alkali metal ceramics, hydrotalcite sorbents, etc.) and catalysts (transition metals, noble metals, bimetallic catalysts, etc.) is summarized. It is pointed out that Ca-based sorbents have cost advantages but poor cyclic stability. Alkali metal ceramic sorbents have CO2 capture capabilities and multi-cyclic stability, but some properties need to be explored. Hydrotalcite sorbents have unique advantages but face many optimization challenges. In terms of catalysts, transition metals have sintering carbon deposition problems that can be improved by modification. Noble metals have high activity but high cost, and the loading capacity needs to be optimized. Bimetallic catalysts have many advantages and are key in the biomass-based feedstock reforming process. In the future, new combinations can be expanded, and interactions with carriers can be studied. The sorption-enhanced technology is combined with various processes, thus creating a way to optimize the overall energy requirements and process configurations. With the help of this combination method, more rational planning can be achieved in terms of energy utilization, and the process configurations can be continuously improved in a more scientific and efficient direction. Coupling with chemical looping can achieve system heat balance, reduce energy consumption, and improve energy utilization efficiency. Coupling with DRM can build a carbon utilization cycle, convert greenhouse gases into valuable fuels and chemicals, and improve reaction performance. And SOFC coupling enables efficient energy conversion, simplifies operating procedures, and improves overall system performance. Although biomass feedstock SESR technology has made progress, the technology still faces many challenges. Future research needs to focus on the following aspects: First, further optimize the performance of sorbents, develop new and highly efficient sorbent materials, conduct in-depth research on the sorption mechanism, improve the cyclic stability and sorption capacity of sorbents, especially focus on the sintering problem of Ca-based sorbents and explore the application of alkali metal ceramic sorbents in biomass steam gasification. For practical biomass applications, sorbent design must address ash-induced deactivation. Second, strengthen the design and optimization of bifunctional materials. By combining theoretical calculations and experimental research, precisely regulate the synergistic effect of catalytic and sorption functions, solve the mismatch problem between catalytic hydrogen production and decarbonization and regeneration reactions, and improve the chemical stability of materials. Third, continuously innovate in catalyst research and development, develop catalysts with low cost, high activity, high selectivity, and high stability, conduct in-depth research on the deactivation mechanism of catalysts, explore new catalyst systems, optimize the preparation process, and improve the resistance to poisoning and long-term stability of catalysts. Practical biomass applications require catalysts tolerant to Cl− or alkali metals. Fourth, deepen the research on technology coupling, optimize the coupling process parameters, solve the engineering problems in the system integration process, improve the overall performance and stability of the system, and promote the SESR technology to move towards large-scale industrial applications. Through continuous efforts in material selection, catalyst impurity resistance optimization, and process integration, SESR technology is expected to achieve further breakthroughs and wide applications in the field of biomass feedstocks, providing strong support for sustainable energy development. Finally, the future development direction of SESR technology for biomass raw materials is prospected. (1) The solar photothermal conversion system can be used to collect solar energy and convert it into heat energy, which provides heat for the biomass reforming reaction in the SESR technology. By designing efficient concentrating and heat collecting devices, the high-temperature heat generated by solar energy can be accurately transferred to the reaction system. As a result, the dependence on traditional fossil energy for heating can be reduced, and the carbon emissions and energy costs in the entire hydrogen production process can be lowered. (2) Explore the combination of the solar photocatalytic process with the SESR technology and develop a new type of photocatalytic-thermocatalytic composite reaction system. During the biomass reforming reaction, take advantage of the active electrons and holes generated by the photocatalyst under light irradiation to further promote the breaking and recombination of chemical bonds in the reaction, thereby improving the generation rate and selectivity of hydrogen. (3) Advanced heat storage technology (such as sensible heat storage, latent heat storage, and thermochemical heat storage) is used to store the intermittent heat supplied from the outside during the operation of SESR technology. When the reaction system needs heat supplementation, for example, during the biomass feedstock feeding stage, the stored heat can be released to maintain the stability of the reaction temperature and ensure the continuous and efficient progress of the reaction. (4) Combine the power generation function of the thermal power plant with the hydrogen production function of the SESR technology of biomass feedstock materials to create a thermal power and hydrogen cogeneration model. During the normal power generation process of the thermal power plant, the waste heat generated by it is utilized to ensure the stable hydrogen production of the SESR technology. The hydrogen produced can be supplied to the surrounding hydrogen energy application scenarios and can also be reused within the thermal power plant for power generation. In short, the SESR technology of biomass feedstock has broad development space and many directions to explore in the future. Through continuous innovation and optimization in multiple dimensions, it is expected to play a more important role in the development of sustainable energy and create a cleaner, more efficient, and sustainable energy future for human society. Changjian Yuan received his MS degree from Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics in 2024. After that, he entered Huazhong University of Science and Technology to pursue a PhD degree. Currently, his research interest is the design and development of bifunctional materials for hydrogen production by sorption-enhanced steam reforming of biomass. Long Jiang received his PhD degree from Huazhong University of Science and Technology in 2013. He studied and worked at King Abdullah University of Science and Technology in Saudi Arabia from 2017 to 2019. He is currently an associate professor at Huazhong University of Science and Technology. His research interests include efficient and clean conversion of biomass waste to hydrogen/biofuels and smart, flexible power generation. Song Hu received his PhD degree from Huazhong University of Science and Technology in 2002. In 2005, he was funded by the Humboldt Foundation of Germany to study and work at the University of Bayreuth. He is currently a professor at Huazhong University of Science and Technology and the director of the Research Center of the China-Europe Clean and Renewable Energy Academy. He is mainly engaged in the research of biomass thermal reaction mechanism and new application technology, traditional fossil energy efficient and clean reaction mechanism and application technology, and resource utilization of various renewable energy. Jun Xiang received his PhD degree from Huazhong University of Science and Technology in 2000. He is currently a professor at Huazhong University of Science and Technology, deputy director of the National Key Laboratory of Coal Combustion and Low Carbon Utilization, and an Outstanding Huazhong Scholar. His main research interests include combustion theory, pollutant generation and control, carbon materials, new power cycle systems, and solid waste resource utilization.

coredata.dc:description: In response to the urgent global need to address climate change, reduce emissions, and ensure energy security, hydrogen plays a crucial role in the global energy transition. However, traditional hydrogen production methods, such as fossil fuel-based steam reforming and water electrolysis, face significant environmental and economic challenges. As an abundant renewable resource, biomass has attracted much attention for hydrogen production technology, particularly sorption-enhanced steam reforming (SESR). This technology combines the principles of chemical equilibrium and sorption to capture CO2 using solid sorbents, thereby enhancing the efficiency and purity of hydrogen production from biomass-derived syngas. It offers advantages such as reduced costs, lower energy consumption, decreased emissions, and customization for specific applications. Although SESR technology has demonstrated excellent hydrogen production performance, existing reviews mainly focus on model compounds and still lack critical analysis of its performance in real biomass application scenarios. This review provides a critical summary of the research progress of biomass feedstocks and model compounds SESR for hydrogen production, detailing the effects of feedstock characteristics, temperature, steam ratio, CO2 sorbent (CaO, alkali metal ceramics, and hydrotalcite), and catalysts on gas yield. In addition, it further emphasizes the research progress of advanced sorption-catalysis bifunctional composite materials and discusses the coupling application of SESR technology with other processes. The review concludes by highlighting the outstanding challenges of SESR technology and focusing on future research directions, aiming to provide theoretical support and insights for the further development of sorption-enhanced biomass hydrogen production technology.
